Subject: Your request  for Telework: 100% has been received
Body:
Office of the Chief Information Officer

OAST ACMS Notification


 

MAX MEINDL,

The FEMA Reasonable Accommodations Unit at the Office of Equal Rights (OER) is pleased to inform you that your request for reasonable accommodation has been received.

Your ticket number RAR0046767 has been assigned to the FEMA RA Section Chief for assignment to a FEMA RA Specialist.   

The assigned RA Specialist will contact you to provide guidance on next steps in the RA process. To expedite processing upon OER review, please ensure both a copy of your FEMA Form 256-0-1 Request for Reasonable Accommodation <https://snow.dhs.gov/sys_attachment.do?sys_id=5e972f7a1b35ad10c9eaa759bc4bcb7c>  and supporting medical documentation of disability are uploaded to your RA ticket in ACMS. Supporting medical documentation may not be required if your disability and need for accommodation is visible. Please be aware that if required, sufficient medical documentation must come from a medical professional familiar with your disability, must be on their letterhead, signed, dated, and must contain all of the following information:

Criteria for sufficient medical documentation:

1.	Describes the nature, severity, and duration of the individual’s impairment;
2.	The major life activity or activities that the impairment limits;
3.	The extent to which the impairment limits the individual’s ability to perform said activity or activities;
4.	Substantiates why the requested reasonable accommodation is needed to perform essential functions of the job.

To obtain a status of your RA request, contact the assigned RA Specialist or email fema-reasonable-accommodation@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:fema-reasonable-accommodation@fema.dhs.gov> 

 

** For privacy reasons, DO NOT EMAIL or FAX MEDICAL DOCUMENTS to the DHS Accessibility Help Desk! ** 

 

 

 

 

This is an official notification from the DHS Office of Accessible Systems & Technology (OAST). To unsubscribe from future notifications please access your Notification Preferences <https://dhs.servicenowservices.com/sp?id=alert_preferences> .

Subject: fyi
Body:
Denial of a Request

If a request for reasonable accommodation is denied or partially denied, notification of the decision must be provided in writing within 5 business days of the request for accommodation being denied and must specifically state the reason for the denial.

 

Thank you for your assistance.

From: Clemons, Shelia (CTR) <shelia.clemons@associates.fema.dhs.gov> 
Sent: Wednesday, July 10, 2024 11:22 AM
To: Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: RA Meeting Request

 

Good afternoon Mr. Meindl: 

   

On January 2, 2024, you submitted a request for a Reasonable Accommodation that is pending action. Per the RA instruction, FEMA Reasonable Accommodation Policy <https://www.fema.gov/sites/default/files/documents/fema_reasonable-accommodation-policy.pdf>  the timeframe for processing an accommodation is 45 days. The Disability Support Branch regrets the unavoidable delay, but is now prepared to service your request. To proceed we’d like to schedule an initial 15-30 minute meeting to review your request; after which we will contact and confirm that your Supervisor of Record (SOR) has awareness of your request for an accommodation. After an initial meeting with each, our office will arrange a joint interactive session to discuss accommodation options.   

  

Please provide a copy of your Position Description (PD) prior to the initial meeting; you may obtain a copy from your SOR or HR Specialist. If you have not already done so, please complete page one of the FEMA Form 256-0-1 Request for Reasonable Accommodation.  <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/OER%20Forms/Request%20Reasonable%20Accommodation%20Form%20256-0-1.pdf> Additionally, we encourage you to review the attached  FEMA Fact Sheet Guide to the Reasonable Accommodation Process and Deployments. <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=%2Fsites%2FOAI%2Fooer%2FDocuments%2FLaws%2C%20Authorities%2C%20Statements%2FRA%20Policies%2FReasonable%20Accommodation%20Process%20During%20Deployment%5FFact%20Sheet%5F508v%2Epdf&parent=%2Fsites%2FOAI%2Fooer%2FDocuments%2FLaws%2C%20Authorities%2C%20Statements%2FRA%20Policies>  The fact sheet explains the RA process in a nutshell, outlines the criteria that must be met to be considered a qualified person with a disability, as well as the criteria for sufficient medical documentation. Please note that we cannot proceed with processing an accommodation request before we receive adequate medical documentation.  The ADA requires an employer to provide reasonable accommodations to qualified individuals with disabilities who are employees or applicants for employment, unless to do so would cause an undue hardship. The ADA defines an individual with a disability as a person who experiences substantial impairment in performing one or more major life activities, such as walking and hearing.  

   

During the initial meeting we will also review the following:  

1.	the RA process;  
2.	roles and responsibilities;   
3.	timelines;   
4.	interactive process/discussion;  
5.	medical documentation;  
6.	definition of effective accommodation; and,  
7.	review your position description.  
	.  

Please confirm if you are available for an initial 15-30 minute meeting on July 11, 2024, anytime between 2:00 -3:30 pm EST any time on Friday, July 12th after 11L00 am. EST.  If these dates do not work for you, please let me know a convenient time to discuss your RA request..   

  

For tracking purposes, you must respond to this email using the same subject line.  

   

Thank you for your patience and contact us with any questions.    

  

Respectfully, Shelia Clemons  

Reasonable Accommodation| Disability Support Branch| Office of Civil Rights  

FEMA | U.S. Department of Homeland Security  

FEMA-OCR-RA@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:FEMA-OCR-RA@fema.dhs.gov>

Subject: Read: RA Meeting Request
Body:
Your message 

   To: Clemons, Shelia (CTR)
   Subject: RE: RA Meeting Request
   Sent: Thursday, July 11, 2024 1:33:06 PM (UTC-05:00) Eastern Time (US & Canada)

 was read on Thursday, July 11, 2024 2:17:15 PM (UTC-05:00) Eastern Time (US & Canada).

Subject: Medical Documentation Request
Body:
Mr. Meindl:

I was a pleasure talking with you a few minutes ago.  As indicated, the one medical statement currently on file is insufficient to substantiate your RA request.  The letter fails to meet the criteria outlined below:    

  

Criteria for sufficient medical documentation:  

1.      Describes the nature, severity, and duration of the individual's condition;  

2.      The activity or activities that the condition limits;  

3.      The extent to which the condition limits the individual’s ability to perform said activity or activities; and,  

4.      Substantiates why the requested reasonable accommodation, is needed.  

  

If you have not done so already, we encourage you to discuss your accommodation(s) you are requesting, and the list of criteria for sufficient medical documentation with your medical provider. Submit additional medical documentation as a password protected or encrypted document using the same email thread and subject line.  Passwords may be shared in a separate email, with the same email subject line for tracking purposes. All correspondence must be on the office letterhead of a licensed healthcare provider, dated, and signed (wet signature preferred). If needed, your medical provider may fill out the attached “medical request form” and sign it rather than writing a letter with the required items. 

  

The requested information is due to our office within 14 calendar days (July 26, 2024).    Please contact me if you have any questions.

   

Thanks, 

 Shelia

Shelia Clemons

Contract RA Specialist| Disability Unit| Office of Civil Rights 

FEMA | U.S. Department of Homeland Security 

Phone: |Fax: 540-504-2223 | Preferred pronouns:  

Reasonable Accommodation (RA) (sharepoint.com) <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/SitePages/Reasonable-Accommodation-(RA).aspx>

1.      Describes the nature, severity, and duration of the individual's condition;  

2.      The activity or activities that the condition limits;  

3.      The extent to which the condition limits the individual’s ability to perform said activity or activities; and,  

4.      Substantiates why the requested reasonable accommodation, is needed.  

  

If you have not done so already, we encourage you to discuss your accommodation(s) you are requesting, and the list of criteria for sufficient medical documentation with your medical provider. Submit additional medical documentation as a password protected or encrypted document using the same email thread and subject line.  Passwords may be shared in a separate email, with the same email subject line for tracking purposes. All correspondence must be on the office letterhead of a licensed healthcare provider, dated, and signed (wet signature preferred). If needed, your medical provider may fill out the attached “medical request form” and sign it rather than writing a letter with the required items. 

  

The requested information is due to our office within 14 calendar days (July 26, 2024).    Please contact me if you have any questions.

   

Thanks, 

 Shelia

Shelia Clemons

Contract RA Specialist| Disability Unit| Office of Civil Rights 

FEMA | U.S. Department of Homeland Security 

Phone: |Fax: 540-504-2223 | Preferred pronouns:  

Reasonable Accommodation (RA) (sharepoint.com) <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/SitePages/Reasonable-Accommodation-(RA).aspx>

Subject: Fwd: RA Meeting Request
Body:
Get Outlook for iOS <https://aka.ms/o0ukef> 
________________________________

From: Clemons, Shelia (CTR) <shelia.clemons@associates.fema.dhs.gov>
Sent: Wednesday, July 10, 2024 11:22:00 AM
To: Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: RA Meeting Request 
 

Good afternoon Mr. Meindl: 

   

On January 2, 2024, you submitted a request for a Reasonable Accommodation that is pending action. Per the RA instruction, FEMA Reasonable Accommodation Policy <https://www.fema.gov/sites/default/files/documents/fema_reasonable-accommodation-policy.pdf>  the timeframe for processing an accommodation is 45 days. The Disability Support Branch regrets the unavoidable delay, but is now prepared to service your request. To proceed we’d like to schedule an initial 15-30 minute meeting to review your request; after which we will contact and confirm that your Supervisor of Record (SOR) has awareness of your request for an accommodation. After an initial meeting with each, our office will arrange a joint interactive session to discuss accommodation options.   

  

Please provide a copy of your Position Description (PD) prior to the initial meeting; you may obtain a copy from your SOR or HR Specialist. If you have not already done so, please complete page one of the FEMA Form 256-0-1 Request for Reasonable Accommodation.  <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/OER%20Forms/Request%20Reasonable%20Accommodation%20Form%20256-0-1.pdf> Additionally, we encourage you to review the attached  FEMA Fact Sheet Guide to the Reasonable Accommodation Process and Deployments. <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=%2Fsites%2FOAI%2Fooer%2FDocuments%2FLaws%2C%20Authorities%2C%20Statements%2FRA%20Policies%2FReasonable%20Accommodation%20Process%20During%20Deployment%5FFact%20Sheet%5F508v%2Epdf&parent=%2Fsites%2FOAI%2Fooer%2FDocuments%2FLaws%2C%20Authorities%2C%20Statements%2FRA%20Policies>  The fact sheet explains the RA process in a nutshell, outlines the criteria that must be met to be considered a qualified person with a disability, as well as the criteria for sufficient medical documentation. Please note that we cannot proceed with processing an accommodation request before we receive adequate medical documentation.  The ADA requires an employer to provide reasonable accommodations to qualified individuals with disabilities who are employees or applicants for employment, unless to do so would cause an undue hardship. The ADA defines an individual with a disability as a person who experiences substantial impairment in performing one or more major life activities, such as walking and hearing.  

   

During the initial meeting we will also review the following:  

1.	the RA process;  
2.	roles and responsibilities;   
3.	timelines;   
4.	interactive process/discussion;  
5.	medical documentation;  
6.	definition of effective accommodation; and,  
7.	review your position description.  
	.  

Please confirm if you are available for an initial 15-30 minute meeting on July 11, 2024, anytime between 2:00 -3:30 pm EST any time on Friday, July 12th after 11L00 am. EST.  If these dates do not work for you, please let me know a convenient time to discuss your RA request..   

  

For tracking purposes, you must respond to this email using the same subject line.  

   

Thank you for your patience and contact us with any questions.    

  

Respectfully, Shelia Clemons  

Reasonable Accommodation| Disability Support Branch| Office of Civil Rights  

FEMA | U.S. Department of Homeland Security  

FEMA-OCR-RA@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:FEMA-OCR-RA@fema.dhs.gov>   

 



 WARNING: This document and attachments are for official use only. It is to be controlled, stored, handled, transmitted, distributed and disposed of in accordance with DHS policy relating to For Official Use Only (FOUO) information. This information shall not be distributed beyond the original addressee without prior authorization of the originator. This communication along with any attachments is covered by Federal and state laws governing electronic communications and may contain restricted and legally privileged information. Unauthorized disclosure of this information may result in personal liability with civil and criminal penalties. If the reader of this message is not the intended recipient or has received it in error, do not disseminate copy or otherwise use the information. Please reply immediately to the sender and delete this message.

From: Clemons, Shelia (CTR) <shelia.clemons@associates.fema.dhs.gov> 
Sent: Thursday, July 11, 2024 2:32 PM
To: Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: Medical Documentation Request

 

Mr. Meindl:

I was a pleasure talking with you a few minutes ago.  As indicated, the one medical statement currently on file is insufficient to substantiate your RA request.  The letter fails to meet the criteria outlined below:    

  

Criteria for sufficient medical documentation:  

1.      Describes the nature, severity, and duration of the individual's condition;  

2.      The activity or activities that the condition limits;  

3.      The extent to which the condition limits the individual’s ability to perform said activity or activities; and,  

4.      Substantiates why the requested reasonable accommodation, is needed.  

  

If you have not done so already, we encourage you to discuss your accommodation(s) you are requesting, and the list of criteria for sufficient medical documentation with your medical provider. Submit additional medical documentation as a password protected or encrypted document using the same email thread and subject line.  Passwords may be shared in a separate email, with the same email subject line for tracking purposes. All correspondence must be on the office letterhead of a licensed healthcare provider, dated, and signed (wet signature preferred). If needed, your medical provider may fill out the attached “medical request form” and sign it rather than writing a letter with the required items. 

  

The requested information is due to our office within 14 calendar days (July 26, 2024).    Please contact me if you have any questions.

   

Thanks, 

 Shelia

Shelia Clemons

Contract RA Specialist| Disability Unit| Office of Civil Rights 

FEMA | U.S. Department of Homeland Security

Subject: Medical Documentation Request
Body:
Max:

After our discussion, I went back to look at the initial medical documentation that is in the file.  That medical documentation dated in December 2023, indicated that you have several chronic illnesses.  The medical documentation that you submitted dated July 23, 2024, speaks to your need to care for your wife and nothing about your illnesses.  As we spoke, I indicated that the RA process is for the individual and not to care for your wife.  Since there is the medical statement that you have chronic illnesses, I am asking that you again provide medical documentation to support your specific need for a reasonable accommodation that is not related to the care of your wife.   The medical documentation contained in your file and submitted to me by you is not sufficient to support your RA request.  I am therefore requesting any new medical documentation be received no later than August 2, 2024 and must meet the following:

 

1.      Describes the nature, severity, and duration of your medical impairment; 

2.      The major life activity or activities that the impairment limits;  

3.      The extent to which the impairment limits your ability to perform said activity or activities; and

4.      Substantiates why the requested reasonable accommodation is needed to perform essential functions of the job. 

 

Should you have any problems with this request, please reach out to me.

Respectfully,

 

Shelia

Shelia Clemons

Contract RA Specialist| Disability Unit| Office of Civil Rights 

FEMA | U.S. Department of Homeland Security 

Phone: |Fax: 540-504-2223 | Preferred pronouns:  

Reasonable Accommodation (RA) (sharepoint.com) <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/SitePages/Reasonable-Accommodation-(RA).aspx>

2.       The major life activity or activities that the impairment limits;  

3.       The extent to which the impairment limits your ability to perform said activity or activities; and

4.       Substantiates why the requested reasonable accommodation is needed to perform essential functions of the job. 

 

Should you have any problems with this request, please reach out to me.

Respectfully,

 

Shelia

From: Clemons, Shelia (CTR) <shelia.clemons@associates.fema.dhs.gov> 
Sent: Wednesday, July 24, 2024 3:01 PM
To: Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: Medical Documentation Request

 

Max:

After our discussion, I went back to look at the initial medical documentation that is in the file.  That medical documentation dated in December 2023, indicated that you have several chronic illnesses.  The medical documentation that you submitted dated July 23, 2024, speaks to your need to care for your wife and nothing about your illnesses.  As we spoke, I indicated that the RA process is for the individual and not to care for your wife.  Since there is the medical statement that you have chronic illnesses, I am asking that you again provide medical documentation to support your specific need for a reasonable accommodation that is not related to the care of your wife.   The medical documentation contained in your file and submitted to me by you is not sufficient to support your RA request.  I am therefore requesting any new medical documentation be received no later than August 2, 2024 and must meet the following:

 

1.      Describes the nature, severity, and duration of your medical impairment; 

2.      The major life activity or activities that the impairment limits;  

3.      The extent to which the impairment limits your ability to perform said activity or activities; and

4.      Substantiates why the requested reasonable accommodation is needed to perform essential functions of the job. 

 

Should you have any problems with this request, please reach out to me.

Respectfully,

 

Shelia

Shelia Clemons

Contract RA Specialist| Disability Unit| Office of Civil Rights

Subject: RA Decision
Body:
Good afternoon Meindl,   

  

As per policy and the interactive discussion that was held on today, “If an employee is denied their request for reasonable accommodation, they may appeal directly to their second level supervisor within ten (10) calendar days of the employee’s receipt of the decision. The employee may present additional information in support of their request. The second level supervisor will respond to this request within ten (10) calendar days of receipt of the request. The appeal decision must be reviewed by OCR within ten (10) days prior to issuance.” 

  

Your second line SOR is Jodi Hunter. Please submit your request directly to Jodi Hunter and copy me, (RA Specialist) for awareness purposes and to begin the interactive process for the appeal.  

  

You have been provided with the FF-256 page 2 Management Response decision document and any additional questions regarding the grounds for the initial denial may be discussed with your SOR.  

  

Shelia Clemons

Respectfully,   

Reasonable Accommodation| Disability Support Branch| Office of Civil Rights  

FEMA | U.S. Department of Homeland Security  

FEMA-OCR-RA@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:FEMA-OCR-RA@fema.dhs.gov>

To: Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov>
Cc: In, Anthony <anthony.in@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: RA Decision

 

Good afternoon Meindl,   

  

As per policy and the interactive discussion that was held on today, “If an employee is denied their request for reasonable accommodation, they may appeal directly to their second level supervisor within ten (10) calendar days of the employee’s receipt of the decision. The employee may present additional information in support of their request. The second level supervisor will respond to this request within ten (10) calendar days of receipt of the request. The appeal decision must be reviewed by OCR within ten (10) days prior to issuance.” 

  

Your second line SOR is Jodi Hunter. Please submit your request directly to Jodi Hunter and copy me, (RA Specialist) for awareness purposes and to begin the interactive process for the appeal.  

  

You have been provided with the FF-256 page 2 Management Response decision document and any additional questions regarding the grounds for the initial denial may be discussed with your SOR.  

  

Shelia Clemons

Respectfully,

Good Afternoon – 

 

I have been tasked with verifying accountability for all staff scheduled to be in office on their designated days for the Houston office. I understand there is a pending Reasonable Accommodation request for Max. Below is an outline of the steps necessary to determine next action items for Max in the process re: his selected days in office for the Houston campus, as advised through discussion with Mission Support. 

 

*	When did employee initiate the Reasonable Accommodation request? Determine how long he has been out of the office. 

 

*	Identify employee’s RA specialist (person tasked with his RA request since beginning process) and reach out to them about the pending request. If specific person cannot be located then email stated inquiries to the Reasonable Accommodations mailbox. 

 

*	Inquire where in the process the request is. What items, documents, or other necessary items are necessary to complete the process for request to be satisfied.  

 

*	Additionally, has employee been approved by SOR to telework from residence 100%? If so, was it a 90 day approval? Dates needed to show when approval was recorded. (Depending on length of time and if considered temporary, a reasonable accommodation request might not be necessary with SOR’s approval.)

 

I am attempting to answer some of Max’s questions on next steps he needs to take and identify how the request can be settled through the proper guidelines we were given. If further clarification is needed please reach out to Karina Aguilo from Mission Support to advise.  

 

Thank you, 

 

Andrew O’Donovan

Complex Projects Coordinator | Texas Integration and Recovery Office | Region 6

From: Aybar-Morales, Miriam <miriam.aybarmorales@fema.dhs.gov> 
Sent: Thursday, August 4, 2022 2:28 PM
To: Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov>
Cc: Mckenzie, Rachel <rachel.mckenzie@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: RE: RAR0042452 for Telework: 100% 

 

Thank you for contacting the OER Disability Unit <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/SitePages/Reasonable-Accommodation-(RA).aspx> .  The OER Disability Unit provides oversight to ensure the timely processing of your RA request is consistent with all relevant statutes, regulations, EEOC, case law and the FEMA Reasonable Accommodation Policy. The deciding official for your RA request is your first line supervisor of record (SOR).  In that regard OER provides neutral, authoritative guidance to both managers/supervisors and employees on the RA process.

 

Attached is the FEMA Form 256-0-1 Request for Reasonable Accommodation <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/OER%20Forms/Request%20Reasonable%20Accommodation%20Form%20256-0-1.pdf> , as well as the FEMA Fact Sheet Guide to the Reasonable Accommodation Process and Deployments. <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=%2Fsites%2FOAI%2Fooer%2FDocuments%2FLaws%2C%20Authorities%2C%20Statements%2FRA%20Policies%2FReasonable%20Accommodation%20Process%20During%20Deployment%5FFact%20Sheet%5F508v%2Epdf&parent=%2Fsites%2FOAI%2Fooer%2FDocuments%2FLaws%2C%20Authorities%2C%20Statements%2FRA%20Policies>  The fact sheet explains the RA process in a nutshell, outlines the criteria that must be met to be considered a qualified person with a disability, as well as the criteria for sufficient medical documentation. Please note that we cannot proceed with processing your accommodation request before we receive adequate medical documentation.  The ADA requires an employer to provide reasonable accommodations to qualified individuals with disabilities who are employees or applicants for employment, unless to do so would cause an undue hardship. The ADA defines an individual with a disability as a person who experiences substantial impairment in performing one or more major life activities, such as walking and hearing.  

 

I understand that you have requested “Continued Remote/telework, permanent exemption from the report to office mandate.

“ as an RA for disability. Note that an RA for disability is never permanent and must be reassessed annually. Furthermore, requests for indefinite periods of full-time telework are considered requests for remote work and are subject to the policy and procedures outlined in the  Remote Work Manual <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/MSFOW/WorkplacePolicyandForms/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=%2Fsites%2FMSFOW%2FWorkplacePolicyandForms%2FRemote%20Work&viewid=5e80857f%2D6001%2D4c4a%2Dad58%2Dc7d8ac04e446> . Remote work is not considered an RA for disability, due to the aforementioned policy limiting the effective dates of an approved RA to one calendar year. 

 

If you wish to pursue a request for remote work, please let us know by COB on Thursday August 11th,  so that we can update and close this RA ticket in a timely manner. 

 

If you are a person with a disability and wish to request telework as an accommodation for your impairment, please follow the next steps outlined below. A first line supervisor of record may consider granting up to 90 days of full-time situational telework as an RA for disability, a second line supervisor may consider extending a full-time situational telework agreement for up to one year. 

 

NEXT STEPS:

 

To formalize an RA request, please amend page one of your FEMA Form 256 to include the effective dates that you are requesting full-time situational telework. Return the amended 256 to me by COB on Thursday August 18th, along with supporting medical documentation. Medical documentation does not need to be shared with your SOR, and you may choose to remove them from the thread before sending your password protected and/or encrypted medical documentation. Please be aware that sufficient medical documentation must come from a medical professional familiar with your disability, must be on their letterhead, signed, dated, and must contain all of the following information:

 

Criteria for sufficient medical documentation:

1.	Describes the nature, severity, and duration of the individual’s impairment;
2.	The major life activity or activities that the impairment limits; 
3.	The extent to which the impairment limits the individual’s ability to perform said activity or activities; 
4.	Substantiates why the requested reasonable accommodation is needed; and,
5.	Why the individual requires the particular reasonable accommodation requested, as well as 
6.	How the accommodation will assist the individual in performing the essential functions of the job.

 

The DHS COVID Vaccination Medical Exception Form uploaded with this RA request is not sufficient to substantiate an RA request of any kind. Note that this form applies only to requests for exemption from the COVID vaccination mandate, which is not currently enforced by any Federal agency due to legal injunction. If and when DHS-HQ resumes adjudication of vaccine exemption requests, please be sure that they are in receipt of a signed DHS COVID Vaccination Medical Exception Form. For your situational awareness, the document attached to this RA ticket was neither signed nor dated. 

 

Respectfully, 

Miriam Aybar-Morales

Senior RA Specialist – Team Lead – COR II| Disability Unit| Office of Equal Rights

From: Aybar-Morales, Miriam <miriam.aybarmorales@fema.dhs.gov> 
Sent: Thursday, August 4, 2022 2:28 PM

Subject: RE: RAR0042452 for Telework: 100% 

 

Thank you for contacting the OER Disability Unit <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/SitePages/Reasonable-Accommodation-(RA).aspx> .  The OER Disability Unit provides oversight to ensure the timely processing of your RA request is consistent with all relevant statutes, regulations, EEOC, case law and the FEMA Reasonable Accommodation Policy. The deciding official for your RA request is your first line supervisor of record (SOR).  In that regard OER provides neutral, authoritative guidance to both managers/supervisors and employees on the RA process.

 

Attached is the FEMA Form 256-0-1 Request for Reasonable Accommodation <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/OER%20Forms/Request%20Reasonable%20Accommodation%20Form%20256-0-1.pdf> , as well as the FEMA Fact Sheet Guide to the Reasonable Accommodation Process and Deployments. <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=%2Fsites%2FOAI%2Fooer%2FDocuments%2FLaws%2C%20Authorities%2C%20Statements%2FRA%20Policies%2FReasonable%20Accommodation%20Process%20During%20Deployment%5FFact%20Sheet%5F508v%2Epdf&parent=%2Fsites%2FOAI%2Fooer%2FDocuments%2FLaws%2C%20Authorities%2C%20Statements%2FRA%20Policies>  The fact sheet explains the RA process in a nutshell, outlines the criteria that must be met to be considered a qualified person with a disability, as well as the criteria for sufficient medical documentation. Please note that we cannot proceed with processing your accommodation request before we receive adequate medical documentation.  The ADA requires an employer to provide reasonable accommodations to qualified individuals with disabilities who are employees or applicants for employment, unless to do so would cause an undue hardship. The ADA defines an individual with a disability as a person who experiences substantial impairment in performing one or more major life activities, such as walking and hearing.  

 

I understand that you have requested “Continued Remote/telework, permanent exemption from the report to office mandate.

“ as an RA for disability. Note that an RA for disability is never permanent and must be reassessed annually. Furthermore, requests for indefinite periods of full-time telework are considered requests for remote work and are subject to the policy and procedures outlined in the  Remote Work Manual <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/MSFOW/WorkplacePolicyandForms/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=%2Fsites%2FMSFOW%2FWorkplacePolicyandForms%2FRemote%20Work&viewid=5e80857f%2D6001%2D4c4a%2Dad58%2Dc7d8ac04e446> . Remote work is not considered an RA for disability, due to the aforementioned policy limiting the effective dates of an approved RA to one calendar year. 

 

If you wish to pursue a request for remote work, please let us know by COB on Thursday August 11th,  so that we can update and close this RA ticket in a timely manner. 

 

If you are a person with a disability and wish to request telework as an accommodation for your impairment, please follow the next steps outlined below. A first line supervisor of record may consider granting up to 90 days of full-time situational telework as an RA for disability, a second line supervisor may consider extending a full-time situational telework agreement for up to one year. 

 

NEXT STEPS:

 

To formalize an RA request, please amend page one of your FEMA Form 256 to include the effective dates that you are requesting full-time situational telework. Return the amended 256 to me by COB on Thursday August 18th, along with supporting medical documentation. Medical documentation does not need to be shared with your SOR, and you may choose to remove them from the thread before sending your password protected and/or encrypted medical documentation. Please be aware that sufficient medical documentation must come from a medical professional familiar with your disability, must be on their letterhead, signed, dated, and must contain all of the following information:

 

Criteria for sufficient medical documentation:

1.	Describes the nature, severity, and duration of the individual’s impairment;
2.	The major life activity or activities that the impairment limits; 
3.	The extent to which the impairment limits the individual’s ability to perform said activity or activities; 
4.	Substantiates why the requested reasonable accommodation is needed; and,
5.	Why the individual requires the particular reasonable accommodation requested, as well as 
6.	How the accommodation will assist the individual in performing the essential functions of the job.

 

The DHS COVID Vaccination Medical Exception Form uploaded with this RA request is not sufficient to substantiate an RA request of any kind. Note that this form applies only to requests for exemption from the COVID vaccination mandate, which is not currently enforced by any Federal agency due to legal injunction. If and when DHS-HQ resumes adjudication of vaccine exemption requests, please be sure that they are in receipt of a signed DHS COVID Vaccination Medical Exception Form. For your situational awareness, the document attached to this RA ticket was neither signed nor dated. 

 

Respectfully, 

Miriam Aybar-Morales

Senior RA Specialist – Team Lead – COR II| Disability Unit| Office of Equal Rights

Subject: Remote Work Request

 

Max, please see the attached decision from Acting PA Director on your remote work application…

 

The decision is listed at the bottom of form 112.

 

Should you wish to Appeal the decision you can go through the appeal process as described in the attached manual.  See below for more information….

 

1-1.       The Appeal Process

A CORE who wishes to appeal a reprimand, suspension, or removal decision may do so in writing to his or her second level supervisor no later than 5:00 p.m. (the local time of the second level supervisor) on the fifth calendar day following the effective date of the disciplinary action. COREs included within collective bargaining units must follow the procedures for that unit. Oral appeals are not permitted. This appeal process is not applicable to non-disciplinary actions, such as right-sizing, demobilization, or the expiration of appointments.

A.   The CORE may provide a narrative and any documentation that he or she considers relevant for the second level supervisor to consider prior to issuing his or her final decision.

B.   The second level supervisor may gather additional documents that he or she deems necessary to make a final decision. The second level supervisor should complete any additional investigation within five working days of the receipt of a timely appeal and issue a decision within five working days after finishing an investigation.

C.   The Employee Relations Specialist will review the written decision drafted by the second level supervisor prior to its issuance to the CORE. Additionally, the Employee Relations Specialist will gather and preserve any and all additional documents acquired by the second level supervisor to issue the final decision and the final decision itself.

 

Regards,

 

Mark Underhill

	Thank you for contacting the OER Disability Unit <https://urldefense.us/v3/__https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/SitePages/Reasonable-Accommodation-(RA).aspx__;!!BClRuOV5cvtbuNI!CkuZ83eyrm4zAkPDvO6wR-Z--yYHk1bTnSwy0W_6Mh4FT1j0KVjEqNtBisRtbIEeFbAIPSXu4X1MyubU84ZR7EgOqg$> .  The OER Disability Unit provides oversight to ensure the timely processing of your RA request is consistent with all relevant statutes, regulations, EEOC, case law and the FEMA Reasonable Accommodation Policy. The deciding official for your RA request is your first line supervisor of record (SOR).  In that regard OER provides neutral, authoritative guidance to both managers/supervisors and employees on the RA process.

	 

	Attached is the FEMA Form 256-0-1 Request for Reasonable Accommodation <https://urldefense.us/v3/__https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/OER*20Forms/Request*20Reasonable*20Accommodation*20Form*20256-0-1.pdf__;JSUlJSU!!BClRuOV5cvtbuNI!CkuZ83eyrm4zAkPDvO6wR-Z--yYHk1bTnSwy0W_6Mh4FT1j0KVjEqNtBisRtbIEeFbAIPSXu4X1MyubU84a6Zj18Og$> , as well as the FEMA Fact Sheet Guide to the Reasonable Accommodation Process and Deployments. <https://urldefense.us/v3/__https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=*2Fsites*2FOAI*2Fooer*2FDocuments*2FLaws*2C*20Authorities*2C*20Statements*2FRA*20Policies*2FReasonable*20Accommodation*20Process*20During*20Deployment*5FFact*20Sheet*5F508v*2Epdf&parent=*2Fsites*2FOAI*2Fooer*2FDocuments*2FLaws*2C*20Authorities*2C*20Statements*2FRA*20Policies__;JSUlJSUlJSUlJSUlJSUlJSUlJSUlJSUlJSUlJSUlJQ!!BClRuOV5cvtbuNI!CkuZ83eyrm4zAkPDvO6wR-Z--yYHk1bTnSwy0W_6Mh4FT1j0KVjEqNtBisRtbIEeFbAIPSXu4X1MyubU84ZwUWS8xQ$>  The fact sheet explains the RA process in a nutshell, outlines the criteria that must be met to be considered a qualified person with a disability, as well as the criteria for sufficient medical documentation. Please note that we cannot proceed with processing your accommodation request before we receive adequate medical documentation.  The ADA requires an employer to provide reasonable accommodations to qualified individuals with disabilities who are employees or applicants for employment, unless to do so would cause an undue hardship. The ADA defines an individual with a disability as a person who experiences substantial impairment in performing one or more major life activities, such as walking and hearing.  

	 

	I understand that you have requested “Continued Remote/telework, permanent exemption from the report to office mandate.

	“ as an RA for disability. Note that an RA for disability is never permanent and must be reassessed annually. Furthermore, requests for indefinite periods of full-time telework are considered requests for remote work and are subject to the policy and procedures outlined in the  Remote Work Manual <https://urldefense.us/v3/__https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/MSFOW/WorkplacePolicyandForms/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=*2Fsites*2FMSFOW*2FWorkplacePolicyandForms*2FRemote*20Work&viewid=5e80857f*2D6001*2D4c4a*2Dad58*2Dc7d8ac04e446__;JSUlJSUlJSUl!!BClRuOV5cvtbuNI!CkuZ83eyrm4zAkPDvO6wR-Z--yYHk1bTnSwy0W_6Mh4FT1j0KVjEqNtBisRtbIEeFbAIPSXu4X1MyubU84a9cJlyjQ$> . Remote work is not considered an RA for disability, due to the aforementioned policy limiting the effective dates of an approved RA to one calendar year. 

	 

	If you wish to pursue a request for remote work, please let us know by COB on Thursday August 11th,  so that we can update and close this RA ticket in a timely manner. 

	 

	If you are a person with a disability and wish to request telework as an accommodation for your impairment, please follow the next steps outlined below. A first line supervisor of record may consider granting up to 90 days of full-time situational telework as an RA for disability, a second line supervisor may consider extending a full-time situational telework agreement for up to one year. 

	 

	NEXT STEPS:

	 

	To formalize an RA request, please amend page one of your FEMA Form 256 to include the effective dates that you are requesting full-time situational telework. Return the amended 256 to me by COB on Thursday August 18th, along with supporting medical documentation. Medical documentation does not need to be shared with your SOR, and you may choose to remove them from the thread before sending your password protected and/or encrypted medical documentation. Please be aware that sufficient medical documentation must come from a medical professional familiar with your disability, must be on their letterhead, signed, dated, and must contain all of the following information:

	 

	Criteria for sufficient medical documentation:

	1.	Describes the nature, severity, and duration of the individual’s impairment;
	2.	The major life activity or activities that the impairment limits; 
	3.	The extent to which the impairment limits the individual’s ability to perform said activity or activities; 
	4.	Substantiates why the requested reasonable accommodation is needed; and,
	5.	Why the individual requires the particular reasonable accommodation requested, as well as 
	6.	How the accommodation will assist the individual in performing the essential functions of the job.

	 

	The DHS COVID Vaccination Medical Exception Form uploaded with this RA request is not sufficient to substantiate an RA request of any kind. Note that this form applies only to requests for exemption from the COVID vaccination mandate, which is not currently enforced by any Federal agency due to legal injunction. If and when DHS-HQ resumes adjudication of vaccine exemption requests, please be sure that they are in receipt of a signed DHS COVID Vaccination Medical Exception Form. For your situational awareness, the document attached to this RA ticket was neither signed nor dated. 

	 

	Respectfully, 

	Miriam Aybar-Morales

	Senior RA Specialist – Team Lead – COR II| Disability Unit| Office of Equal Rights

Subject: RAR0046767
Body:
My RA has been denied.

How do I validate/verify the required OER/OCC participation/review?

 

RE:

Prior to denying a request for reasonable accommodation for an applicant or employee, the Deciding Official and the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) must consult with the OCC embedded attorney in OCR to articulate the specific reasons for the denial. The Deciding Official in coordination with the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) will draft the denial decision. The OCR Director must review and concur with all denial decisions within 3 business days of the denial decision

 

Thank you for your assistance.

___________________________________

Subject: RE: RAR0046767
Body:
My RA has been denied.

How do I validate/verify the required OER/OCC participation/review?

 

RE: From policy

Prior to denying a request for reasonable accommodation for an applicant or employee, the Deciding Official and the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) must consult with the OCC embedded attorney in OCR to articulate the specific reasons for the denial. The Deciding Official in coordination with the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) will draft the denial decision. The OCR Director must review and concur with all denial decisions within 3 business days of the denial decision

 

From fact sheet.

How is a decision reached regarding a request for a reasonable accommodation? 

FEMA is required to initiate an interactive discussion with individuals who request an accommodation. It is through this discussion that the SOR learns about the employee’s limitations and types of accommodations which would be the most effective to enable the employee to perform the essential functions of his/her job. The SOR may consult with OER, if assistance is needed. The final decision rests with the SOR; however, a SOR may not issue a denial without the concurrence of OER. Once decided, the SOR must meet with the employee to discuss the decision and provide them the decision in writing. Once issued, a copy of the decision must be forwarded to OER.

 

Thank you for your assistance.

___________________________________

Subject: RAR0046767
Body:
My RA has been denied.

How do I validate/verify the required OER/OCC participation/review?

 

1.	From FEMA RA policy 04/2024:

“If you decide to deny an accommodation request, you should provide your response in writing via Appendix D: Management Response to Request for Reasonable Accommodation (attached) to the employee within fifteen (15) business days of receipt of request and provide the RAPM and the DMS Director with a copy. 

The explanation for the denial of the requested accommodation should be written in plain language, clearly stating the specific reasons for the denial; for example, why there is no accommodation that would be effective or why a specific accommodation would result in undue hardship.

• Consult with the RAPM and the Office of the General Counsel, Labor and Employment Law (OGC-LEL) group for legal advice regarding reasonable accommodations and undue hardship prior to transmitting your denial response to the employee. 

For more information about what constitutes “undue hardship,” please consult the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s Enforcement Guidance on “Reasonable Accommodation and Undue Hardship under the Americans with Disabilities Act,” located at http://eeoc.gov/policy/docs/accommodation.html.

2.	RE: From policy

Prior to denying a request for reasonable accommodation for an applicant or employee, the Deciding Official and the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) must consult with the OCC embedded attorney in OCR to articulate the specific reasons for the denial. The Deciding Official in coordination with the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) will draft the denial decision. The OCR Director must review and concur with all denial decisions within 3 business days of the denial decision

 

3.	From fact sheet.

How is a decision reached regarding a request for a reasonable accommodation? 

FEMA is required to initiate an interactive discussion with individuals who request an accommodation. It is through this discussion that the SOR learns about the employee’s limitations and types of accommodations which would be the most effective to enable the employee to perform the essential functions of his/her job. The SOR may consult with OER, if assistance is needed. The final decision rests with the SOR; however, a SOR may not issue a denial without the concurrence of OER. Once decided, the SOR must meet with the employee to discuss the decision and provide them the decision in writing. Once issued, a copy of the decision must be forwarded to OER.

 

 

Thank you for your assistance.

___________________________________

Max J Meindl, PMP

Emergency Management Specialist | PDTFL

My RA has been denied.

How do I validate/verify the required OER/OCC participation/review?

 

1.	From FEMA RA policy 04/2024:

“If you decide to deny an accommodation request, you should provide your response in writing via Appendix D: Management Response to Request for Reasonable Accommodation (attached) to the employee within fifteen (15) business days of receipt of request and provide the RAPM and the DMS Director with a copy. 

The explanation for the denial of the requested accommodation should be written in plain language, clearly stating the specific reasons for the denial; for example, why there is no accommodation that would be effective or why a specific accommodation would result in undue hardship.

• Consult with the RAPM and the Office of the General Counsel, Labor and Employment Law (OGC-LEL) group for legal advice regarding reasonable accommodations and undue hardship prior to transmitting your denial response to the employee. 

For more information about what constitutes “undue hardship,” please consult the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s Enforcement Guidance on “Reasonable Accommodation and Undue Hardship under the Americans with Disabilities Act,” located at http://eeoc.gov/policy/docs/accommodation.html.

2.	RE: From policy

Prior to denying a request for reasonable accommodation for an applicant or employee, the Deciding Official and the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) must consult with the OCC embedded attorney in OCR to articulate the specific reasons for the denial. The Deciding Official in coordination with the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) will draft the denial decision. The OCR Director must review and concur with all denial decisions within 3 business days of the denial decision

 

3.	From fact sheet.

How is a decision reached regarding a request for a reasonable accommodation? 

FEMA is required to initiate an interactive discussion with individuals who request an accommodation. It is through this discussion that the SOR learns about the employee’s limitations and types of accommodations which would be the most effective to enable the employee to perform the essential functions of his/her job. The SOR may consult with OER, if assistance is needed. The final decision rests with the SOR; however, a SOR may not issue a denial without the concurrence of OER. Once decided, the SOR must meet with the employee to discuss the decision and provide them the decision in writing. Once issued, a copy of the decision must be forwarded to OER.

 

 

Thank you for your assistance.

From: Ortiz, Alejandro <alejandro.ortiz@fema.dhs.gov> 
Sent: Monday, August 12, 2024 2:08 PM
To: Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: RE: RAR0046767

 

Good afternoon, Max – 

 

We apologize for the way it’s written in our policy and understand that it may be a bit confusing. The Director of the Office of Civil Rights, and our embedded OCC attorney don’t look at denials until it’s time for your supervisor to issue a final agency denial letter. The 256-0-2 Management Decision from your 1st line and 2nd line are sort of an “intent to deny”. This is because a request isn’t denied by the agency until we’ve exhausted all efforts, to include reassignment as an accommodation of last resort. If you’ve been denied your request for reasonable accommodation, you may appeal directly to your second level supervisor within ten (10) calendar days from the receipt of the decision. During this appeal, you may present additional information in support of your request. The second level supervisor will respond to your request within ten (10) calendar days of receipt of the request. If your 2nd line supervisor also denies the request, you may seek reassignment as an accommodation of last resort in which the agency will attempt to reassign you to a vacant position for which you may be qualified for based on numerous factors (e.g., parameters, experience, etc).

 

If reassignment as an accommodation of last resort is unsuccessful, the agency would have exhausted all efforts in accommodating your need and your leadership will draft a Final Agency Denial Letter for OCR Leadership & OCC review.

 

Let me know if you have additional questions or concerns.

 

Thanks,

 

Alejandro Ortiz

Disability Program Manager (Acting)

Internal Civil Rights Directorate | Disability Support Branch (DSB) | Office of Civil Rights (OCR) 

Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) | U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS)

From: Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov>

To: Accommodations <accommodations@hq.dhs.gov>
Cc: Lagria, Jason <jason.lagria@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: RAR0046767

 

My RA has been denied.

How do I validate/verify the required OER/OCC participation/review?

 

1.	From FEMA RA policy 04/2024:

“If you decide to deny an accommodation request, you should provide your response in writing via Appendix D: Management Response to Request for Reasonable Accommodation (attached) to the employee within fifteen (15) business days of receipt of request and provide the RAPM and the DMS Director with a copy. 

The explanation for the denial of the requested accommodation should be written in plain language, clearly stating the specific reasons for the denial; for example, why there is no accommodation that would be effective or why a specific accommodation would result in undue hardship.

• Consult with the RAPM and the Office of the General Counsel, Labor and Employment Law (OGC-LEL) group for legal advice regarding reasonable accommodations and undue hardship prior to transmitting your denial response to the employee. 

For more information about what constitutes “undue hardship,” please consult the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s Enforcement Guidance on “Reasonable Accommodation and Undue Hardship under the Americans with Disabilities Act,” located at http://eeoc.gov/policy/docs/accommodation.html.

2.	RE: From policy

Prior to denying a request for reasonable accommodation for an applicant or employee, the Deciding Official and the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) must consult with the OCC embedded attorney in OCR to articulate the specific reasons for the denial. The Deciding Official in coordination with the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) will draft the denial decision. The OCR Director must review and concur with all denial decisions within 3 business days of the denial decision

 

3.	From fact sheet.

How is a decision reached regarding a request for a reasonable accommodation? 

FEMA is required to initiate an interactive discussion with individuals who request an accommodation. It is through this discussion that the SOR learns about the employee’s limitations and types of accommodations which would be the most effective to enable the employee to perform the essential functions of his/her job. The SOR may consult with OER, if assistance is needed. The final decision rests with the SOR; however, a SOR may not issue a denial without the concurrence of OER. Once decided, the SOR must meet with the employee to discuss the decision and provide them the decision in writing. Once issued, a copy of the decision must be forwarded to OER.

 

 

Thank you for your assistance.

___________________________________

Max J Meindl, PMP

Emergency Management Specialist | PDTFL

From: Ortiz, Alejandro <alejandro.ortiz@fema.dhs.gov> 
Sent: Monday, August 12, 2024 2:08 PM
To: Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: RE: RAR0046767

 

Good afternoon, Max – 

 

We apologize for the way it’s written in our policy and understand that it may be a bit confusing. The Director of the Office of Civil Rights, and our embedded OCC attorney don’t look at denials until it’s time for your supervisor to issue a final agency denial letter. The 256-0-2 Management Decision from your 1st line and 2nd line are sort of an “intent to deny”. This is because a request isn’t denied by the agency until we’ve exhausted all efforts, to include reassignment as an accommodation of last resort. If you’ve been denied your request for reasonable accommodation, you may appeal directly to your second level supervisor within ten (10) calendar days from the receipt of the decision. During this appeal, you may present additional information in support of your request. The second level supervisor will respond to your request within ten (10) calendar days of receipt of the request. If your 2nd line supervisor also denies the request, you may seek reassignment as an accommodation of last resort in which the agency will attempt to reassign you to a vacant position for which you may be qualified for based on numerous factors (e.g., parameters, experience, etc).

 

If reassignment as an accommodation of last resort is unsuccessful, the agency would have exhausted all efforts in accommodating your need and your leadership will draft a Final Agency Denial Letter for OCR Leadership & OCC review.

 

Let me know if you have additional questions or concerns.

 

Thanks,

 

Alejandro Ortiz

Disability Program Manager (Acting)

Internal Civil Rights Directorate | Disability Support Branch (DSB) | Office of Civil Rights (OCR)

From: Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov> 
Sent: Monday, August 12, 2024 9:36 AM
To: Accommodations <accommodations@hq.dhs.gov>
Cc: Lagria, Jason <jason.lagria@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: RAR0046767

 

My RA has been denied.

How do I validate/verify the required OER/OCC participation/review?

 

1.	From FEMA RA policy 04/2024:

“If you decide to deny an accommodation request, you should provide your response in writing via Appendix D: Management Response to Request for Reasonable Accommodation (attached) to the employee within fifteen (15) business days of receipt of request and provide the RAPM and the DMS Director with a copy. 

The explanation for the denial of the requested accommodation should be written in plain language, clearly stating the specific reasons for the denial; for example, why there is no accommodation that would be effective or why a specific accommodation would result in undue hardship.

• Consult with the RAPM and the Office of the General Counsel, Labor and Employment Law (OGC-LEL) group for legal advice regarding reasonable accommodations and undue hardship prior to transmitting your denial response to the employee. 

For more information about what constitutes “undue hardship,” please consult the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s Enforcement Guidance on “Reasonable Accommodation and Undue Hardship under the Americans with Disabilities Act,” located at http://eeoc.gov/policy/docs/accommodation.html.

2.	RE: From policy

Prior to denying a request for reasonable accommodation for an applicant or employee, the Deciding Official and the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) must consult with the OCC embedded attorney in OCR to articulate the specific reasons for the denial. The Deciding Official in coordination with the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) will draft the denial decision. The OCR Director must review and concur with all denial decisions within 3 business days of the denial decision

 

3.	From fact sheet.

How is a decision reached regarding a request for a reasonable accommodation? 

FEMA is required to initiate an interactive discussion with individuals who request an accommodation. It is through this discussion that the SOR learns about the employee’s limitations and types of accommodations which would be the most effective to enable the employee to perform the essential functions of his/her job. The SOR may consult with OER, if assistance is needed. The final decision rests with the SOR; however, a SOR may not issue a denial without the concurrence of OER. Once decided, the SOR must meet with the employee to discuss the decision and provide them the decision in writing. Once issued, a copy of the decision must be forwarded to OER.

 

 

Thank you for your assistance.

___________________________________

Max J Meindl, PMP

Emergency Management Specialist | PDTFL

Is there a specific format or form, as typical for FEMA, for the appeal to the second level supervisor.

I don’t have anything to add to the file currently (additional information).

Do I leave a voice mail, send an email, MS Teams chat?

Are there any required words/verbiage that are required.

 

This has been a long, frustrating, and lonely process and I appreciate your providing some clarification for me.

I just know all the attention to detail required on my part, (real signatures) and then to receive that “denial” that wasn’t even signed, in my opinion, just add to the confusion.

Is this a real process or a part time endeavor the is very much impacting my life.

The process took 190 days to start after I requested leadership assistance for an expedited review.

(Other RAR have been open for 707 days and 985 and 986 days with no comms.)

 

Thank you for your assistance.

Sent: Monday, August 12, 2024 2:08 PM
To: Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: RE: RAR0046767

 

Good afternoon, Max – 

 

We apologize for the way it’s written in our policy and understand that it may be a bit confusing. The Director of the Office of Civil Rights, and our embedded OCC attorney don’t look at denials until it’s time for your supervisor to issue a final agency denial letter. The 256-0-2 Management Decision from your 1st line and 2nd line are sort of an “intent to deny”. This is because a request isn’t denied by the agency until we’ve exhausted all efforts, to include reassignment as an accommodation of last resort. If you’ve been denied your request for reasonable accommodation, you may appeal directly to your second level supervisor within ten (10) calendar days from the receipt of the decision. During this appeal, you may present additional information in support of your request. The second level supervisor will respond to your request within ten (10) calendar days of receipt of the request. If your 2nd line supervisor also denies the request, you may seek reassignment as an accommodation of last resort in which the agency will attempt to reassign you to a vacant position for which you may be qualified for based on numerous factors (e.g., parameters, experience, etc).

 

If reassignment as an accommodation of last resort is unsuccessful, the agency would have exhausted all efforts in accommodating your need and your leadership will draft a Final Agency Denial Letter for OCR Leadership & OCC review.

 

Let me know if you have additional questions or concerns.

 

Thanks,

 

Alejandro Ortiz

Disability Program Manager (Acting)

Cc: Lagria, Jason <jason.lagria@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: RAR0046767

 

My RA has been denied.

How do I validate/verify the required OER/OCC participation/review?

 

1.	From FEMA RA policy 04/2024:

“If you decide to deny an accommodation request, you should provide your response in writing via Appendix D: Management Response to Request for Reasonable Accommodation (attached) to the employee within fifteen (15) business days of receipt of request and provide the RAPM and the DMS Director with a copy. 

The explanation for the denial of the requested accommodation should be written in plain language, clearly stating the specific reasons for the denial; for example, why there is no accommodation that would be effective or why a specific accommodation would result in undue hardship.

• Consult with the RAPM and the Office of the General Counsel, Labor and Employment Law (OGC-LEL) group for legal advice regarding reasonable accommodations and undue hardship prior to transmitting your denial response to the employee. 

For more information about what constitutes “undue hardship,” please consult the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s Enforcement Guidance on “Reasonable Accommodation and Undue Hardship under the Americans with Disabilities Act,” located at http://eeoc.gov/policy/docs/accommodation.html.

2.	RE: From policy

Prior to denying a request for reasonable accommodation for an applicant or employee, the Deciding Official and the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) must consult with the OCC embedded attorney in OCR to articulate the specific reasons for the denial. The Deciding Official in coordination with the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) will draft the denial decision. The OCR Director must review and concur with all denial decisions within 3 business days of the denial decision

 

3.	From fact sheet.

How is a decision reached regarding a request for a reasonable accommodation? 

FEMA is required to initiate an interactive discussion with individuals who request an accommodation. It is through this discussion that the SOR learns about the employee’s limitations and types of accommodations which would be the most effective to enable the employee to perform the essential functions of his/her job. The SOR may consult with OER, if assistance is needed. The final decision rests with the SOR; however, a SOR may not issue a denial without the concurrence of OER. Once decided, the SOR must meet with the employee to discuss the decision and provide them the decision in writing. Once issued, a copy of the decision must be forwarded to OER.

 

 

Thank you for your assistance.

___________________________________

Max J Meindl, PMP

From: Ortiz, Alejandro <alejandro.ortiz@fema.dhs.gov> 
Sent: Monday, August 12, 2024 2:08 PM
To: Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: RE: RAR0046767

 

Good afternoon, Max – 

 

We apologize for the way it’s written in our policy and understand that it may be a bit confusing. The Director of the Office of Civil Rights, and our embedded OCC attorney don’t look at denials until it’s time for your supervisor to issue a final agency denial letter. The 256-0-2 Management Decision from your 1st line and 2nd line are sort of an “intent to deny”. This is because a request isn’t denied by the agency until we’ve exhausted all efforts, to include reassignment as an accommodation of last resort. If you’ve been denied your request for reasonable accommodation, you may appeal directly to your second level supervisor within ten (10) calendar days from the receipt of the decision. During this appeal, you may present additional information in support of your request. The second level supervisor will respond to your request within ten (10) calendar days of receipt of the request. If your 2nd line supervisor also denies the request, you may seek reassignment as an accommodation of last resort in which the agency will attempt to reassign you to a vacant position for which you may be qualified for based on numerous factors (e.g., parameters, experience, etc).

 

If reassignment as an accommodation of last resort is unsuccessful, the agency would have exhausted all efforts in accommodating your need and your leadership will draft a Final Agency Denial Letter for OCR Leadership & OCC review.

 

Let me know if you have additional questions or concerns.

 

Thanks,

 

Alejandro Ortiz

Disability Program Manager (Acting)

From: Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov>

To: Accommodations <accommodations@hq.dhs.gov>
Cc: Lagria, Jason <jason.lagria@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: RAR0046767

 

My RA has been denied.

How do I validate/verify the required OER/OCC participation/review?

 

1.	From FEMA RA policy 04/2024:

“If you decide to deny an accommodation request, you should provide your response in writing via Appendix D: Management Response to Request for Reasonable Accommodation (attached) to the employee within fifteen (15) business days of receipt of request and provide the RAPM and the DMS Director with a copy. 

The explanation for the denial of the requested accommodation should be written in plain language, clearly stating the specific reasons for the denial; for example, why there is no accommodation that would be effective or why a specific accommodation would result in undue hardship.

• Consult with the RAPM and the Office of the General Counsel, Labor and Employment Law (OGC-LEL) group for legal advice regarding reasonable accommodations and undue hardship prior to transmitting your denial response to the employee. 

For more information about what constitutes “undue hardship,” please consult the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s Enforcement Guidance on “Reasonable Accommodation and Undue Hardship under the Americans with Disabilities Act,” located at http://eeoc.gov/policy/docs/accommodation.html.

2.	RE: From policy

Prior to denying a request for reasonable accommodation for an applicant or employee, the Deciding Official and the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) must consult with the OCC embedded attorney in OCR to articulate the specific reasons for the denial. The Deciding Official in coordination with the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) will draft the denial decision. The OCR Director must review and concur with all denial decisions within 3 business days of the denial decision

 

3.	From fact sheet.

How is a decision reached regarding a request for a reasonable accommodation? 

FEMA is required to initiate an interactive discussion with individuals who request an accommodation. It is through this discussion that the SOR learns about the employee’s limitations and types of accommodations which would be the most effective to enable the employee to perform the essential functions of his/her job. The SOR may consult with OER, if assistance is needed. The final decision rests with the SOR; however, a SOR may not issue a denial without the concurrence of OER. Once decided, the SOR must meet with the employee to discuss the decision and provide them the decision in writing. Once issued, a copy of the decision must be forwarded to OER.

 

 

Thank you for your assistance.

___________________________________

Max J Meindl, PMP

How do I validate/verify the required OER/OCC participation/review?

 

1.	From FEMA RA policy 04/2024:

“If you decide to deny an accommodation request, you should provide your response in writing via Appendix D: Management Response to Request for Reasonable Accommodation (attached) to the employee within fifteen (15) business days of receipt of request and provide the RAPM and the DMS Director with a copy. 

The explanation for the denial of the requested accommodation should be written in plain language, clearly stating the specific reasons for the denial; for example, why there is no accommodation that would be effective or why a specific accommodation would result in undue hardship.

• Consult with the RAPM and the Office of the General Counsel, Labor and Employment Law (OGC-LEL) group for legal advice regarding reasonable accommodations and undue hardship prior to transmitting your denial response to the employee. 

For more information about what constitutes “undue hardship,” please consult the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s Enforcement Guidance on “Reasonable Accommodation and Undue Hardship under the Americans with Disabilities Act,” located at http://eeoc.gov/policy/docs/accommodation.html.

2.	RE: From policy

Prior to denying a request for reasonable accommodation for an applicant or employee, the Deciding Official and the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) must consult with the OCC embedded attorney in OCR to articulate the specific reasons for the denial. The Deciding Official in coordination with the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) will draft the denial decision. The OCR Director must review and concur with all denial decisions within 3 business days of the denial decision

 

3.	From fact sheet.

How is a decision reached regarding a request for a reasonable accommodation? 

FEMA is required to initiate an interactive discussion with individuals who request an accommodation. It is through this discussion that the SOR learns about the employee’s limitations and types of accommodations which would be the most effective to enable the employee to perform the essential functions of his/her job. The SOR may consult with OER, if assistance is needed. The final decision rests with the SOR; however, a SOR may not issue a denial without the concurrence of OER. Are there any required words/verbiage that are required.

 

This has been a long, frustrating, and lonely process and I appreciate your providing some clarification for me.

I just know all the attention to detail required on my part, (real signatures) and then to receive that “denial” that wasn’t even signed, in my opinion, just add to the confusion.

Is this a real process or a part time endeavor the is very much impacting my life.

The process took 190 days to start after I requested leadership assistance for an expedited review.

(Other RAR have been open for 707 days and 985 and 986 days with no comms.)

 

Thank you for your assistance.

Good afternoon, Max – 

 

We apologize for the way it’s written in our policy and understand that it may be a bit confusing. The Director of the Office of Civil Rights, and our embedded OCC attorney don’t look at denials until it’s time for your supervisor to issue a final agency denial letter. The 256-0-2 Management Decision from your 1st line and 2nd line are sort of an “intent to deny”. This is because a request isn’t denied by the agency until we’ve exhausted all efforts, to include reassignment as an accommodation of last resort. If you’ve been denied your request for reasonable accommodation, you may appeal directly to your second level supervisor within ten (10) calendar days from the receipt of the decision. During this appeal, you may present additional information in support of your request. The second level supervisor will respond to your request within ten (10) calendar days of receipt of the request. If your 2nd line supervisor also denies the request, you may seek reassignment as an accommodation of last resort in which the agency will attempt to reassign you to a vacant position for which you may be qualified for based on numerous factors (e.g., parameters, experience, etc).

 

If reassignment as an accommodation of last resort is unsuccessful, the agency would have exhausted all efforts in accommodating your need and your leadership will draft a Final Agency Denial Letter for OCR Leadership & OCC review.

 

Let me know if you have additional questions or concerns.

 

Thanks,

 

Alejandro Ortiz

Subject: RAR0046767

 

My RA has been denied.

How do I validate/verify the required OER/OCC participation/review?

 

1.	From FEMA RA policy 04/2024:

“If you decide to deny an accommodation request, you should provide your response in writing via Appendix D: Management Response to Request for Reasonable Accommodation (attached) to the employee within fifteen (15) business days of receipt of request and provide the RAPM and the DMS Director with a copy. 

The explanation for the denial of the requested accommodation should be written in plain language, clearly stating the specific reasons for the denial; for example, why there is no accommodation that would be effective or why a specific accommodation would result in undue hardship.

• Consult with the RAPM and the Office of the General Counsel, Labor and Employment Law (OGC-LEL) group for legal advice regarding reasonable accommodations and undue hardship prior to transmitting your denial response to the employee. 

For more information about what constitutes “undue hardship,” please consult the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s Enforcement Guidance on “Reasonable Accommodation and Undue Hardship under the Americans with Disabilities Act,” located at http://eeoc.gov/policy/docs/accommodation.html.

2.	RE: From policy

Prior to denying a request for reasonable accommodation for an applicant or employee, the Deciding Official and the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) must consult with the OCC embedded attorney in OCR to articulate the specific reasons for the denial. The Deciding Official in coordination with the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) will draft the denial decision. The OCR Director must review and concur with all denial decisions within 3 business days of the denial decision

 

3.	From fact sheet.

How is a decision reached regarding a request for a reasonable accommodation? 

FEMA is required to initiate an interactive discussion with individuals who request an accommodation. It is through this discussion that the SOR learns about the employee’s limitations and types of accommodations which would be the most effective to enable the employee to perform the essential functions of his/her job. The SOR may consult with OER, if assistance is needed. The final decision rests with the SOR; however, a SOR may not issue a denial without the concurrence of OER. Once decided, the SOR must meet with the employee to discuss the decision and provide them the decision in writing. Once issued, a copy of the decision must be forwarded to OER.

 

 

Thank you for your assistance.

___________________________________

We apologize for the way it’s written in our policy and understand that it may be a bit confusing. The Director of the Office of Civil Rights, and our embedded OCC attorney don’t look at denials until it’s time for your supervisor to issue a final agency denial letter. The 256-0-2 Management Decision from your 1st line and 2nd line are sort of an “intent to deny”. This is because a request isn’t denied by the agency until we’ve exhausted all efforts, to include reassignment as an accommodation of last resort. If you’ve been denied your request for reasonable accommodation, you may appeal directly to your second level supervisor within ten (10) calendar days from the receipt of the decision. During this appeal, you may present additional information in support of your request. The second level supervisor will respond to your request within ten (10) calendar days of receipt of the request. If your 2nd line supervisor also denies the request, you may seek reassignment as an accommodation of last resort in which the agency will attempt to reassign you to a vacant position for which you may be qualified for based on numerous factors (e.g., parameters, experience, etc).

 

If reassignment as an accommodation of last resort is unsuccessful, the agency would have exhausted all efforts in accommodating your need and your leadership will draft a Final Agency Denial Letter for OCR Leadership & OCC review.

 

Let me know if you have additional questions or concerns.

 

Thanks,
