Subject: Request to consider Reassignment - Reasonable Accommodation of Last Resort

 

Good morning, Max,

 

After the interactive process considering your position description (attached), the essential functions of your position, and your request for an accommodation (to work from home 100%), management has denied your reasonable accommodation request for the reasons indicated in the attached 256-02 form.

 

If you believe that you are no longer able to perform the essential functions of your position, you may request that the Agency consider reassigning you if there is a funded, open position, consistent with page 19 of the attached FEMA Instruction on Reasonable Accommodation.  Please note that all FEMA positions require the ability to deploy and other positions may not be able to facilitate an accommodation that requires 100% work from home without the ability to deploy.  

 

If you would like to go this route, please respond by COB no later than August 23, 2024.

 

Respectfully,

Anna Myers

From: Meindl, Max 
Sent: Thursday, August 22, 2024 8:45 AM
To: Myers, Anna <anna.myers4@fema.dhs.gov>
Cc: Ortiz, Alejandro <alejandro.ortiz@fema.dhs.gov>; Dyson, Alisa <alisa.dyson@fema.dhs.gov>; Hershey, Jodi <jodi.hershey@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: RE: Request to consider Reassignment - Reasonable Accommodation of Last Resort

 

Anna,

 

I do not believe that I am no longer able to perform the essential functions of the specified position.

I am limited in my ability to “physically” deploy, obviously due to health issues.

*This may impact the preferred way or process that my SOR and second line SOR utilize, so, out of a sense of professionalism, I will defer to their preferred process.

I was blissfully unaware that the position required 50 weeks physical deployment per year.  I don’t recall that information being provided during the interview.

If you can access the job interview transcript, it is very clear that I was not aware of that requirement.

When told that information by SOR in first conversation, well.. we started discussing how to unwind the situation because I couldn’t physically deploy.

The only “interactive process” I had was one formal conversation with SOR and RA personnel.

Hence, here we are.

This specific RAR was opened on 01/02/2024 and after contacting leadership, it was moved up to expedited. 

This happened after being in the que for 190 days. 

So, I do appreciate the absurdity of the note to “reply no later than” sort of stuff after experiencing no response to 5 RAR over the years.  

This RAR sits for months and then gets turbocharged in mere days, all to the detriment of my position, or at least that is how I currently feel.

Ignored, abused, dismissed.

Is this really the purpose of the program?

 

This snip was taken around 02/24/24, so add days as appropriate.

The RA requests, never get adjudicated.  



Respondent comments

1.            My understanding, at this time, is that the “essential function” impact identified is “deployment”.

2.            I can and do provide the essential functions and elements of the PDTFL position assist, PDTFL duties and responsibilities.

3.            The majority of my time with FEMA has been in a virtual status. 

4.            Primarily due to declining health

5.            For the past few years, a proactive SOR and assistive leadership sought out and provided an effective accommodation process that enabled me to enjoy the privileges and benefits of employment.

6.            I have been virtually deployed (03/2020-05/2023),  38 months    (add 9 months for temporary duty with limited assignments since 12/2023, when I could have been deployed virtually to assist practically anywhere)

7.            I have physically deployed (09/2017-06/2018 (+/-) and 05/2023-11/2023.  15 months

8.            In office guess (06/2018-03/2020).          21 months

9.            I do acknowledge limitations due to various conditions as stipulated in the appropriate documents and these do impact my physical ability to deploy.

10.         It does not impact my ability to deploy virtually as I have been doing since 03/2020.

11.         There was a short field deployment (05/23-11/23) to 4705DR, which was a problematic with a medical event being tossed into the mix.

12.         I was under the assumption we were exploring options for accommodation, maybe short term if appropriate, and Tony and I were developing an accommodation that might work, a discussion to deploy to Houston was had on 05/29/24.

13.         When asked by my SOR on 05/29/24 if I could deploy to Houston, I concurred and 9 minutes later he called back and told me he was overruled.

14.         In subsequent conversations with my SOR, discussing my being under-utilized and the deployment option to Houston being dismissed I asked why, and the response was that he was told to stand down on this issue.

15.         From my perspective, my SOR, at that time and maybe still is, the “deciding official” was working with me, both of us trying to work something out, which we did, and his decision was overruled.

16.         Why?

17.         I would like to assume it was because of a concern over my health.

18.         If so, why not a virtual deployment option?

19.         I have spoken with SOR many times about my concerns over being underutilized and how I could do more for the mission.

20.         I was deployed, virtually, to 4611DR, (09/2021-05/2023) as a PDTFL.



21.         I worked virtually from 03/2020-09/2021.

22.         One 6-month deployment since 03/2020, which was problematic

 

                Much of the following has not been addressed in the denial.

The denial must clearly state the specific reasons for the denial, which shall include, where applicable:

Why the requested accommodation would not be effective;

Why the requested accommodation would result in undue hardship to the Agency;

Whether medical documentation provided was inadequate to establish that the individual has a disability and/or needs a reasonable accommodation.

Whether the requested accommodation would require the removal of an essential job function; or

Whether the requested accommodation would require the lowering of a performance or production standard.

 

.

 

Thank you for your assistance.

___________________________________

Max J Meindl, PMP

Emergency Management Specialist | PDTFL

From: Myers, Anna <anna.myers4@fema.dhs.gov> 
Sent: Friday, August 16, 2024 10:33 AM
To: Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov>
Cc: Ortiz, Alejandro <alejandro.ortiz@fema.dhs.gov>; Dyson, Alisa <alisa.dyson@fema.dhs.gov>; Hershey, Jodi <jodi.hershey@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: Request to consider Reassignment - Reasonable Accommodation of Last Resort

 

Good morning, Max,

 

After the interactive process considering your position description (attached), the essential functions of your position, and your request for an accommodation (to work from home 100%), management has denied your reasonable accommodation request for the reasons indicated in the attached 256-02 form.

 

If you believe that you are no longer able to perform the essential functions of your position, you may request that the Agency consider reassigning you if there is a funded, open position, consistent with page 19 of the attached FEMA Instruction on Reasonable Accommodation.  Please note that all FEMA positions require the ability to deploy and other positions may not be able to facilitate an accommodation that requires 100% work from home without the ability to deploy.  

 

If you would like to go this route, please respond by COB no later than August 23, 2024.

 

Respectfully,

Anna Myers

EEO Specialist, Reasonable Accommodation (RA)

Disability Support Branch | Office of Civil Rights (OCR)

Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) | U. S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS)

Subject: Meindl, Max: Request to consider Reassignment - Reasonable Accommodation of Last Resort

 

Good afternoon, 

 

Thank you for contacting the EEO Branch via email on 8/22/2024.  Employees, former employees, and applicants who believe they have been discriminated against or subjected to harassment because of a protected category must consult with and initiate an informal EEO complaint with an EEO counselor.  Employees, former employees, and applicants must contact an EEO counselor within 45 calendar days of the matter believed to be discriminatory, or in the case of a personnel action, within 45 calendar days of the effective date of that action. 

 

I have attached some additional information pertaining to the EEO process and other resources available.  If you would like to contact the FEMA Office of Civil Rights to file an EEO Complaint, you may do so by phone at 202-212-3535 or by returning the attached intake form via email to FEMA-OCR-EEO@FEMA.DHS.GOV.

 

Respectfully,

 

Tara 

 

Office of Civil Rights – EEO Branch

 

Federal Emergency Management Agency 

www.FEMA.gov <http://www.fema.gov/>

Subject: Meindl, Max: Request to consider Reassignment - Reasonable Accommodation of Last Resort

 

Good afternoon, 

 

Thank you for contacting the EEO Branch via email on 8/22/2024.  Employees, former employees, and applicants who believe they have been discriminated against or subjected to harassment because of a protected category must consult with and initiate an informal EEO complaint with an EEO counselor.  Employees, former employees, and applicants must contact an EEO counselor within 45 calendar days of the matter believed to be discriminatory, or in the case of a personnel action, within 45 calendar days of the effective date of that action. 

 

I have attached some additional information pertaining to the EEO process and other resources available.  If you would like to contact the FEMA Office of Civil Rights to file an EEO Complaint, you may do so by phone at 202-212-3535 or by returning the attached intake form via email to FEMA-OCR-EEO@FEMA.DHS.GOV.

 

Respectfully,

 

Tara 

 

Office of Civil Rights – EEO Branch

 

Federal Emergency Management Agency 

www.FEMA.gov <http://www.fema.gov/>

From: Meindl, Max 
Sent: Thursday, August 22, 2024 8:45 AM
To: Myers, Anna <anna.myers4@fema.dhs.gov>
Cc: Ortiz, Alejandro <alejandro.ortiz@fema.dhs.gov>; Dyson, Alisa <alisa.dyson@fema.dhs.gov>; Hershey, Jodi <jodi.hershey@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: RE: Request to consider Reassignment - Reasonable Accommodation of Last Resort

 

Anna,

 

I do not believe that I am no longer able to perform the essential functions of the specified position.

I am limited in my ability to “physically” deploy, obviously due to health issues.

*This may impact the preferred way or process that my SOR and second line SOR utilize, so, out of a sense of professionalism, I will defer to their preferred process.

I was blissfully unaware that the position required 50 weeks physical deployment per year.  I don’t recall that information being provided during the interview.

If you can access the job interview transcript, it is very clear that I was not aware of that requirement.

When told that information by SOR in first conversation, well.. we started discussing how to unwind the situation because I couldn’t physically deploy.

The only “interactive process” I had was one formal conversation with SOR and RA personnel.

Hence, here we are.

This specific RAR was opened on 01/02/2024 and after contacting leadership, it was moved up to expedited. 

This happened after being in the que for 190 days. 

So, I do appreciate the absurdity of the note to “reply no later than” sort of stuff after experiencing no response to 5 RAR over the years.  

This RAR sits for months and then gets turbocharged in mere days, all to the detriment of my position, or at least that is how I currently feel.

Ignored, abused, dismissed.

Is this really the purpose of the program?

 

This snip was taken around 02/24/24, so add days as appropriate.

The RA requests, never get adjudicated.  



Respondent comments

1.            My understanding, at this time, is that the “essential function” impact identified is “deployment”.

2.            I can and do provide the essential functions and elements of the PDTFL position assist, PDTFL duties and responsibilities.

3.            The majority of my time with FEMA has been in a virtual status. 

4.            Primarily due to declining health

5.            For the past few years, a proactive SOR and assistive leadership sought out and provided an effective accommodation process that enabled me to enjoy the privileges and benefits of employment.

6.            I have been virtually deployed (03/2020-05/2023),  38 months    (add 9 months for temporary duty with limited assignments since 12/2023, when I could have been deployed virtually to assist practically anywhere)

7.            I have physically deployed (09/2017-06/2018 (+/-) and 05/2023-11/2023.  15 months

8.            In office guess (06/2018-03/2020).          21 months

9.            I do acknowledge limitations due to various conditions as stipulated in the appropriate documents and these do impact my physical ability to deploy.

10.         It does not impact my ability to deploy virtually as I have been doing since 03/2020.

11.         There was a short field deployment (05/23-11/23) to 4705DR, which was a problematic with a medical event being tossed into the mix.

12.         I was under the assumption we were exploring options for accommodation, maybe short term if appropriate, and Tony and I were developing an accommodation that might work, a discussion to deploy to Houston was had on 05/29/24.

13.         When asked by my SOR on 05/29/24 if I could deploy to Houston, I concurred and 9 minutes later he called back and told me he was overruled.

14.         In subsequent conversations with my SOR, discussing my being under-utilized and the deployment option to Houston being dismissed I asked why, and the response was that he was told to stand down on this issue.

15.         From my perspective, my SOR, at that time and maybe still is, the “deciding official” was working with me, both of us trying to work something out, which we did, and his decision was overruled.

16.         Why?

17.         I would like to assume it was because of a concern over my health.

18.         If so, why not a virtual deployment option?

19.         I have spoken with SOR many times about my concerns over being underutilized and how I could do more for the mission.

20.         I was deployed, virtually, to 4611DR, (09/2021-05/2023) as a PDTFL.



21.         I worked virtually from 03/2020-09/2021.

22.         One 6-month deployment since 03/2020, which was problematic

 

                Much of the following has not been addressed in the denial.

The denial must clearly state the specific reasons for the denial, which shall include, where applicable:

Why the requested accommodation would not be effective;

Why the requested accommodation would result in undue hardship to the Agency;

Whether medical documentation provided was inadequate to establish that the individual has a disability and/or needs a reasonable accommodation.

Whether the requested accommodation would require the removal of an essential job function; or

Whether the requested accommodation would require the lowering of a performance or production standard.

 

.

 

Thank you for your assistance.

___________________________________

Max J Meindl, PMP

Emergency Management Specialist | PDTFL

Subject: Request to consider Reassignment - Reasonable Accommodation of Last Resort

 

Good morning, Max,

 

After the interactive process considering your position description (attached), the essential functions of your position, and your request for an accommodation (to work from home 100%), management has denied your reasonable accommodation request for the reasons indicated in the attached 256-02 form.

 

If you believe that you are no longer able to perform the essential functions of your position, you may request that the Agency consider reassigning you if there is a funded, open position, consistent with page 19 of the attached FEMA Instruction on Reasonable Accommodation.  Please note that all FEMA positions require the ability to deploy and other positions may not be able to facilitate an accommodation that requires 100% work from home without the ability to deploy.  

 

If you would like to go this route, please respond by COB no later than August 23, 2024.

 

Respectfully,

Anna Myers

EEO Specialist, Reasonable Accommodation (RA)

Disability Support Branch | Office of Civil Rights (OCR)

From: Kelley, Janet <janet.kelley@fema.dhs.gov> 
Sent: Tuesday, September 17, 2024 2:10 PM
To: Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: EEO Contact -HS-FEMA-03389-2024

 

Greetings,

I am an Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) Specialist with the Office of Civil Rights (OCR), Internal Civil Rights Division (ICRD), Equal Employment Opportunity Branch (EEOB) and I have been assigned as the counselor for your informal EEO complaint. 

First, I would like to provide some information about the process and what to expect. The EEO process for a federal employee or job applicant, ensures your rights under federal civil rights laws that protect you from discrimination because of your race, color, religion, sex (including gender identity, sexual orientation, and pregnancy), national origin, age (40 or older), disability, or genetic information. The law also protects you from retaliation if you oppose employment discrimination, file a complaint of discrimination, or participate in the EEO complaint process (even if the complaint is not yours.) The OCR EEO office is neutral in the processing of all complaints, and we do not advocate for the complainant or the agency, we instead ensure the administrative process is executed according to the EEOC MD-110, 29 CFR 1614 and other federal laws as applicable.

When a decision is made in an EEO complaint the EEOC Administrative Judge (AJ) or the DHS- Civil Rights and Civil Liberties (CRCL) Final Agency Decision (FAD) writer will be looking at whether the complaint shows a connection or nexus between the actions taken in the complaint and the protected basis(es) claimed. The AJ or CRCL FAD writer will then look at whether management provided a non-discriminatory reason for taking that action. Please keep that in mind when providing information or supporting documentation for your complaint. The process looks at whether discrimination or harassment occurred because of a protected basis. The Agency has other avenues to address complaints that are not based on an EEO protected category, let us know if you need that information.

The first stage of the EEO process is informal counseling. We will have an initial interview where we will discuss: 1.) the EEO process, your role, and your rights and responsibilities, 2.) your complaint and the issues that you are bringing as part of your EEO complaint, and 3.) next steps in the EEO process.  In addition, I am providing some important information attached regarding the EEO process (see attached).   

The intake form was already completed with by you. If you have not done so already, please provide a timeline of events for the instances you wish to include in your EEO Complaint.  Be sure to include dates (mm/dd/yy) of when the alleged incidents in your complaint occurred. If you don’t have the exact date, please try to provide at least the month and year of when the alleged incident(s) occurred. Attached are several documents required to get the process started. 

Our records reflect your initial contact date with EEOB as July 25, 2024, when we received an e-mail/call from you on this date.  Since I only have 30 days from initial contact to counsel your case and to attempt an informal resolution in accordance with applicable EEO regulations, I have attached an extension request that extends the informal counseling period an additional 60 days to ensure we have sufficient time for informal counseling.  If you agree to the extension, please read, sign, and return that document as well.  Also attached is your Notice of Rights and Responsibilities in the EEO process. Please read and initial each line and sign and return. If you have any questions, we can discuss them when we meet.

During the informal EEO process, you have the right to elect traditional EEO counseling or Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) as an option to resolve your complaint.  In traditional EEO counseling, the assigned EEO counselor serves as a go between and communicates your concerns and remedies requested to management and attempts to resolve the issue(s), as well as conducts a limited inquiry to collect additional information regarding your claims. ADR or mediation is an informal meeting between you and management that is conducted by a neutral mediator. The mediator is trained to help people who have disagreements talk to each other.  The mediator does not decide who is right or wrong or issue a decision.  During mediation you can voice your concerns and the mediator assists all parties in effectively communicating. The mediator does not decide who is right or wrong or issue a decision.  Instead, the mediator helps the parties work out their own solutions to their dispute. 

 There are real advantages to participating in ADR.  ADR offers both you and the agency the opportunity for a fast and informal settlement of the dispute.  Rather than leaving the decision to a third party (such as an Administrative Judge), ADR gives you the opportunity to reach an agreement that works for both you and the agency. During mediation all parties are together in one room or over Teams/Zoom. The process begins with the mediator explaining the procedure. Each party gets an opportunity to tell their side of the dispute. If a settlement is reached, a written agreement is drawn up, signed by all parties, and is binding by all parties. This process is voluntary and highly recommended in resolving workplace disputes at the lowest level.

Once I get all your information back, I would like to set up a time for us to discuss your concerns.  The EEO process is time sensitive so please return all your documents to me within 2 business days.  Also, could you please include your working hours and availability when you return your information? 

Please choose one of the current available dates:

•             Wednesday, 18, 2024-

               9:00am – 10:00am (EST)

               10:00am –11:00 am (EST)

              11:00 am EST-12:00 pm (EST)

•             

Please reach out to me if you have any questions.

 

 

V/R

 

 

 

Janet Kelley

Equal Employment Specialist

Office: Office of Civil Rights (OCR) 

FEMA, Department of Homeland Security

Email: janet.kelley@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:janet.kelley@fema.dhs.gov>  I Pronouns: she/her

Subject: EEO Contact -HS-FEMA-03389-2024

 

Greetings,

I am an Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) Specialist with the Office of Civil Rights (OCR), Internal Civil Rights Division (ICRD), Equal Employment Opportunity Branch (EEOB) and I have been assigned as the counselor for your informal EEO complaint. 

First, I would like to provide some information about the process and what to expect. The EEO process for a federal employee or job applicant, ensures your rights under federal civil rights laws that protect you from discrimination because of your race, color, religion, sex (including gender identity, sexual orientation, and pregnancy), national origin, age (40 or older), disability, or genetic information. The law also protects you from retaliation if you oppose employment discrimination, file a complaint of discrimination, or participate in the EEO complaint process (even if the complaint is not yours.) The OCR EEO office is neutral in the processing of all complaints, and we do not advocate for the complainant or the agency, we instead ensure the administrative process is executed according to the EEOC MD-110, 29 CFR 1614 and other federal laws as applicable.

When a decision is made in an EEO complaint the EEOC Administrative Judge (AJ) or the DHS- Civil Rights and Civil Liberties (CRCL) Final Agency Decision (FAD) writer will be looking at whether the complaint shows a connection or nexus between the actions taken in the complaint and the protected basis(es) claimed. The AJ or CRCL FAD writer will then look at whether management provided a non-discriminatory reason for taking that action. Please keep that in mind when providing information or supporting documentation for your complaint. The process looks at whether discrimination or harassment occurred because of a protected basis. The Agency has other avenues to address complaints that are not based on an EEO protected category, let us know if you need that information.

The first stage of the EEO process is informal counseling. We will have an initial interview where we will discuss: 1.) the EEO process, your role, and your rights and responsibilities, 2.) your complaint and the issues that you are bringing as part of your EEO complaint, and 3.) next steps in the EEO process.  In addition, I am providing some important information attached regarding the EEO process (see attached).   

The intake form was already completed with by you. If you have not done so already, please provide a timeline of events for the instances you wish to include in your EEO Complaint.  Be sure to include dates (mm/dd/yy) of when the alleged incidents in your complaint occurred. If you don’t have the exact date, please try to provide at least the month and year of when the alleged incident(s) occurred. Attached are several documents required to get the process started. 

Our records reflect your initial contact date with EEOB as July 25, 2024, when we received an e-mail/call from you on this date.  Since I only have 30 days from initial contact to counsel your case and to attempt an informal resolution in accordance with applicable EEO regulations, I have attached an extension request that extends the informal counseling period an additional 60 days to ensure we have sufficient time for informal counseling.  If you agree to the extension, please read, sign, and return that document as well.  Also attached is your Notice of Rights and Responsibilities in the EEO process. Please read and initial each line and sign and return. If you have any questions, we can discuss them when we meet.

During the informal EEO process, you have the right to elect traditional EEO counseling or Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) as an option to resolve your complaint.  In traditional EEO counseling, the assigned EEO counselor serves as a go between and communicates your concerns and remedies requested to management and attempts to resolve the issue(s), as well as conducts a limited inquiry to collect additional information regarding your claims. ADR or mediation is an informal meeting between you and management that is conducted by a neutral mediator. The mediator is trained to help people who have disagreements talk to each other.  The mediator does not decide who is right or wrong or issue a decision.  During mediation you can voice your concerns and the mediator assists all parties in effectively communicating. The mediator does not decide who is right or wrong or issue a decision.  Instead, the mediator helps the parties work out their own solutions to their dispute. 

 There are real advantages to participating in ADR.  ADR offers both you and the agency the opportunity for a fast and informal settlement of the dispute.  Rather than leaving the decision to a third party (such as an Administrative Judge), ADR gives you the opportunity to reach an agreement that works for both you and the agency. During mediation all parties are together in one room or over Teams/Zoom. The process begins with the mediator explaining the procedure. Each party gets an opportunity to tell their side of the dispute. If a settlement is reached, a written agreement is drawn up, signed by all parties, and is binding by all parties. This process is voluntary and highly recommended in resolving workplace disputes at the lowest level.

Once I get all your information back, I would like to set up a time for us to discuss your concerns.  The EEO process is time sensitive so please return all your documents to me within 2 business days.  Also, could you please include your working hours and availability when you return your information? 

Please choose one of the current available dates:

•             Wednesday, 18, 2024-

               9:00am – 10:00am (EST)

               10:00am –11:00 am (EST)

              11:00 am EST-12:00 pm (EST)

•             

Please reach out to me if you have any questions.

 

 

V/R

 

 

 

Janet Kelley

Equal Employment Specialist

Office: Office of Civil Rights (OCR) 

FEMA, Department of Homeland Security

Email: janet.kelley@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:janet.kelley@fema.dhs.gov>  I Pronouns: she/her

Subject: EEO Contact -HS-FEMA-03389-2024
Body:
Greetings,

I am an Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) Specialist with the Office of Civil Rights (OCR), Internal Civil Rights Division (ICRD), Equal Employment Opportunity Branch (EEOB) and I have been assigned as the counselor for your informal EEO complaint. 

First, I would like to provide some information about the process and what to expect. The EEO process for a federal employee or job applicant, ensures your rights under federal civil rights laws that protect you from discrimination because of your race, color, religion, sex (including gender identity, sexual orientation, and pregnancy), national origin, age (40 or older), disability, or genetic information. The law also protects you from retaliation if you oppose employment discrimination, file a complaint of discrimination, or participate in the EEO complaint process (even if the complaint is not yours.) The OCR EEO office is neutral in the processing of all complaints, and we do not advocate for the complainant or the agency, we instead ensure the administrative process is executed according to the EEOC MD-110, 29 CFR 1614 and other federal laws as applicable.

When a decision is made in an EEO complaint the EEOC Administrative Judge (AJ) or the DHS- Civil Rights and Civil Liberties (CRCL) Final Agency Decision (FAD) writer will be looking at whether the complaint shows a connection or nexus between the actions taken in the complaint and the protected basis(es) claimed. The AJ or CRCL FAD writer will then look at whether management provided a non-discriminatory reason for taking that action. Please keep that in mind when providing information or supporting documentation for your complaint. The process looks at whether discrimination or harassment occurred because of a protected basis. The Agency has other avenues to address complaints that are not based on an EEO protected category, let us know if you need that information.

The first stage of the EEO process is informal counseling. We will have an initial interview where we will discuss: 1.) the EEO process, your role, and your rights and responsibilities, 2.) your complaint and the issues that you are bringing as part of your EEO complaint, and 3.) next steps in the EEO process.  In addition, I am providing some important information attached regarding the EEO process (see attached).   

The intake form was already completed with by you. If you have not done so already, please provide a timeline of events for the instances you wish to include in your EEO Complaint.  Be sure to include dates (mm/dd/yy) of when the alleged incidents in your complaint occurred. If you don’t have the exact date, please try to provide at least the month and year of when the alleged incident(s) occurred. Attached are several documents required to get the process started. 

Our records reflect your initial contact date with EEOB as July 25, 2024, when we received an e-mail/call from you on this date.  Since I only have 30 days from initial contact to counsel your case and to attempt an informal resolution in accordance with applicable EEO regulations, I have attached an extension request that extends the informal counseling period an additional 60 days to ensure we have sufficient time for informal counseling.  If you agree to the extension, please read, sign, and return that document as well.  Also attached is your Notice of Rights and Responsibilities in the EEO process. Please read and initial each line and sign and return. If you have any questions, we can discuss them when we meet.

During the informal EEO process, you have the right to elect traditional EEO counseling or Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) as an option to resolve your complaint.  In traditional EEO counseling, the assigned EEO counselor serves as a go between and communicates your concerns and remedies requested to management and attempts to resolve the issue(s), as well as conducts a limited inquiry to collect additional information regarding your claims. ADR or mediation is an informal meeting between you and management that is conducted by a neutral mediator. The mediator is trained to help people who have disagreements talk to each other.  The mediator does not decide who is right or wrong or issue a decision.  During mediation you can voice your concerns and the mediator assists all parties in effectively communicating. The mediator does not decide who is right or wrong or issue a decision.  Instead, the mediator helps the parties work out their own solutions to their dispute. 

 There are real advantages to participating in ADR.  ADR offers both you and the agency the opportunity for a fast and informal settlement of the dispute.  Rather than leaving the decision to a third party (such as an Administrative Judge), ADR gives you the opportunity to reach an agreement that works for both you and the agency. During mediation all parties are together in one room or over Teams/Zoom. The process begins with the mediator explaining the procedure. Each party gets an opportunity to tell their side of the dispute. If a settlement is reached, a written agreement is drawn up, signed by all parties, and is binding by all parties. This process is voluntary and highly recommended in resolving workplace disputes at the lowest level.

Once I get all your information back, I would like to set up a time for us to discuss your concerns.  The EEO process is time sensitive so please return all your documents to me within 2 business days.  Also, could you please include your working hours and availability when you return your information? 

Please choose one of the current available dates:

•             Wednesday, 18, 2024-

               9:00am – 10:00am (EST)

               10:00am –11:00 am (EST)

              11:00 am EST-12:00 pm (EST)

•             

Please reach out to me if you have any questions.

 

 

V/R

 

 

 

Janet Kelley

Equal Employment Specialist

Office: Office of Civil Rights (OCR) 

FEMA, Department of Homeland Security

Email: janet.kelley@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:janet.kelley@fema.dhs.gov>  I Pronouns: she/her

Each party gets an opportunity to tell their side of the dispute. If a settlement is reached, a written agreement is drawn up, signed by all parties, and is binding by all parties. This process is voluntary and highly recommended in resolving workplace disputes at the lowest level.

Once I get all your information back, I would like to set up a time for us to discuss your concerns.  The EEO process is time sensitive so please return all your documents to me within 2 business days.  Also, could you please include your working hours and availability when you return your information?

From: Kelley, Janet <janet.kelley@fema.dhs.gov>

Subject: EEO Contact -HS-FEMA-03389-2024

 

Greetings,

I am an Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) Specialist with the Office of Civil Rights (OCR), Internal Civil Rights Division (ICRD), Equal Employment Opportunity Branch (EEOB) and I have been assigned as the counselor for your informal EEO complaint. 

First, I would like to provide some information about the process and what to expect. The EEO process for a federal employee or job applicant, ensures your rights under federal civil rights laws that protect you from discrimination because of your race, color, religion, sex (including gender identity, sexual orientation, and pregnancy), national origin, age (40 or older), disability, or genetic information. The law also protects you from retaliation if you oppose employment discrimination, file a complaint of discrimination, or participate in the EEO complaint process (even if the complaint is not yours.) The OCR EEO office is neutral in the processing of all complaints, and we do not advocate for the complainant or the agency, we instead ensure the administrative process is executed according to the EEOC MD-110, 29 CFR 1614 and other federal laws as applicable.

When a decision is made in an EEO complaint the EEOC Administrative Judge (AJ) or the DHS- Civil Rights and Civil Liberties (CRCL) Final Agency Decision (FAD) writer will be looking at whether the complaint shows a connection or nexus between the actions taken in the complaint and the protected basis(es) claimed. The AJ or CRCL FAD writer will then look at whether management provided a non-discriminatory reason for taking that action. Please keep that in mind when providing information or supporting documentation for your complaint. The process looks at whether discrimination or harassment occurred because of a protected basis. The Agency has other avenues to address complaints that are not based on an EEO protected category, let us know if you need that information.

The first stage of the EEO process is informal counseling. We will have an initial interview where we will discuss: 1.) the EEO process, your role, and your rights and responsibilities, 2.) your complaint and the issues that you are bringing as part of your EEO complaint, and 3.) next steps in the EEO process.  In addition, I am providing some important information attached regarding the EEO process (see attached).   

The intake form was already completed with by you. If you have not done so already, please provide a timeline of events for the instances you wish to include in your EEO Complaint.  Be sure to include dates (mm/dd/yy) of when the alleged incidents in your complaint occurred. If you don’t have the exact date, please try to provide at least the month and year of when the alleged incident(s) occurred. Attached are several documents required to get the process started. 

Our records reflect your initial contact date with EEOB as July 25, 2024, when we received an e-mail/call from you on this date.  Since I only have 30 days from initial contact to counsel your case and to attempt an informal resolution in accordance with applicable EEO regulations, I have attached an extension request that extends the informal counseling period an additional 60 days to ensure we have sufficient time for informal counseling.  If you agree to the extension, please read, sign, and return that document as well.  Also attached is your Notice of Rights and Responsibilities in the EEO process. Please read and initial each line and sign and return. If you have any questions, we can discuss them when we meet.

During the informal EEO process, you have the right to elect traditional EEO counseling or Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) as an option to resolve your complaint.  In traditional EEO counseling, the assigned EEO counselor serves as a go between and communicates your concerns and remedies requested to management and attempts to resolve the issue(s), as well as conducts a limited inquiry to collect additional information regarding your claims. ADR or mediation is an informal meeting between you and management that is conducted by a neutral mediator. The mediator is trained to help people who have disagreements talk to each other.  The mediator does not decide who is right or wrong or issue a decision.  During mediation you can voice your concerns and the mediator assists all parties in effectively communicating. The mediator does not decide who is right or wrong or issue a decision.  Instead, the mediator helps the parties work out their own solutions to their dispute. 

 There are real advantages to participating in ADR.  ADR offers both you and the agency the opportunity for a fast and informal settlement of the dispute.  Rather than leaving the decision to a third party (such as an Administrative Judge), ADR gives you the opportunity to reach an agreement that works for both you and the agency. During mediation all parties are together in one room or over Teams/Zoom. The process begins with the mediator explaining the procedure. Each party gets an opportunity to tell their side of the dispute. If a settlement is reached, a written agreement is drawn up, signed by all parties, and is binding by all parties. This process is voluntary and highly recommended in resolving workplace disputes at the lowest level.

Once I get all your information back, I would like to set up a time for us to discuss your concerns.  The EEO process is time sensitive so please return all your documents to me within 2 business days.  Also, could you please include your working hours and availability when you return your information?

               9:00am – 10:00am (EST)

               10:00am –11:00 am (EST)

              11:00 am EST-12:00 pm (EST)

•             

Please reach out to me if you have any questions.

If you agree to the extension, please read, sign, and return that document as well.  Also attached is your Notice of Rights and Responsibilities in the EEO process. Please read and initial each line and sign and return. If you have any questions, we can discuss them when we meet.

During the informal EEO process, you have the right to elect traditional EEO counseling or Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) as an option to resolve your complaint.  In traditional EEO counseling, the assigned EEO counselor serves as a go between and communicates your concerns and remedies requested to management and attempts to resolve the issue(s), as well as conducts a limited inquiry to collect additional information regarding your claims. ADR or mediation is an informal meeting between you and management that is conducted by a neutral mediator. The mediator is trained to help people who have disagreements talk to each other.  The mediator does not decide who is right or wrong or issue a decision.  During mediation you can voice your concerns and the mediator assists all parties in effectively communicating. The mediator does not decide who is right or wrong or issue a decision.  Instead, the mediator helps the parties work out their own solutions to their dispute. 

 There are real advantages to participating in ADR.  ADR offers both you and the agency the opportunity for a fast and informal settlement of the dispute.  Rather than leaving the decision to a third party (such as an Administrative Judge), ADR gives you the opportunity to reach an agreement that works for both you and the agency. During mediation all parties are together in one room or over Teams/Zoom. The process begins with the mediator explaining the procedure. Each party gets an opportunity to tell their side of the dispute. If a settlement is reached, a written agreement is drawn up, signed by all parties, and is binding by all parties. This process is voluntary and highly recommended in resolving workplace disputes at the lowest level.

Once I get all your information back, I would like to set up a time for us to discuss your concerns.  The EEO process is time sensitive so please return all your documents to me within 2 business days.  Also, could you please include your working hours and availability when you return your information? 

Please choose one of the current available dates:

•             Wednesday, 18, 2024-

               9:00am – 10:00am (EST)

               10:00am –11:00 am (EST)

              11:00 am EST-12:00 pm (EST)

•             

Please reach out to me if you have any questions.

 

 

V/R

 

 

 

Janet Kelley

Equal Employment Specialist

Office: Office of Civil Rights (OCR) 

FEMA, Department of Homeland Security

Email: janet.kelley@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:janet.kelley@fema.dhs.gov>  I Pronouns: she/her

Subject: RE: EEO Contact -HS-FEMA-03389-2024
Body:
***This Reasonable accommodation request (RAR), filed on 01/02/2024.  

A response was initiated, after I requested assistance from leadership, on 07/10/2024.  

That is 190 days after filing the request.  Previously filed RAR’s are represented below.  137 days should be added to each of the dates below.  

The remaining RAR, those not deleted along with the medical records, have been open as follows: 

RAR0046767 has been open for 190 days before any action, 

RAR0042452 has been open for 707 days, 

RAR0023278 has been open for 985 days and 

RAR0023261 has been open an astonishing 986 days.

 

*** Good morning, Max, After the interactive process considering your position description (attached), the essential functions of your position, and your request for an accommodation (to work from home 100%), management has denied your reasonable accommodation request for the reasons indicated in the attached 256-02 form. If you believe that you are no longer able to perform the essential functions of your position, you may request that the Agency consider reassigning you if there is a funded, open position, consistent with page 19 of the attached FEMA Instruction on Reasonable Accommodation.  Please note that all FEMA positions require the ability to deploy and other positions may not be able to facilitate an accommodation that requires 100% work from home without the ability to deploy.  If you would like to go this route, please respond by COB no later than August 23, 2024.  Respectfully,  Anna Myers, EEO Specialist, Reasonable Accommodation (RA).

 

***My reply.

Anna, 

I do not believe that I am no longer able to perform the essential functions of the specified position.

I am limited in my ability to “physically” deploy, obviously due to health issues.

*This may impact the preferred way or process that my SOR and second line SOR utilize, so, out of a sense of professionalism, I will defer to their preferred process.

I was blissfully unaware that the position required 50 weeks physical deployment per year.  I don’t recall that information being provided during the interview.

If you can access the job interview transcript, it is very clear that I was not aware of that requirement.

When told that information by SOR in first conversation, well.. we started discussing how to unwind the situation because I couldn’t physically deploy.

The only “interactive process” I had was one formal conversation with SOR and RA personnel.

Hence, here we are.

This specific RAR was opened on 01/02/2024 and after contacting leadership, it was moved up to expedited. 

This happened after being in the que for 190 days. 

So, I do appreciate the absurdity of the note to “reply no later than” sort of stuff after experiencing no response to 5 RAR over the years.  

This RAR sits for months and then gets turbocharged in mere days, all to the detriment of my position, or at least that is how I currently feel.

Ignored, abused, dismissed.

Is this really the purpose of the program?

This snip was taken around 02/24/24, so add days as appropriate.

The RA requests, never get adjudicated.  

Respondent comments

1.            My understanding, at this time, is that the “essential function” impact identified is “deployment”.

2.            I can and do provide the essential functions and elements of the PDTFL position assist, PDTFL duties and responsibilities.

3.            The majority of my time with FEMA has been in a virtual status. 

4.            Primarily due to declining health

5.            For the past few years, a proactive SOR and assistive leadership sought out and provided an effective accommodation process that enabled me to enjoy the privileges and benefits of employment.

6.            I have been virtually deployed (03/2020-05/2023),  38 months    (add 9 months for temporary duty with limited assignments since 12/2023, when I could have been deployed virtually to assist practically anywhere)

7.            I have physically deployed (09/2017-06/2018 (+/-) and 05/2023-11/2023.  15 months

8.            In office guess (06/2018-03/2020).          21 months

9.            I do acknowledge limitations due to various conditions as stipulated in the appropriate documents and these do impact my physical ability to deploy.

10.         It does not impact my ability to deploy virtually as I have been doing since 03/2020.

11.         There was a short field deployment (05/23-11/23) to 4705DR, which was a problematic with a medical event being tossed into the mix.

12.         I was under the assumption we were exploring options for accommodation, maybe short term if appropriate, and Tony and I were developing an accommodation that might work, a discussion to deploy to Houston was had on 05/29/24.

13.         When asked by my SOR on 05/29/24 if I could deploy to Houston, I concurred and 9 minutes later he called back and told me he was overruled.

14.         In subsequent conversations with my SOR, discussing my being under-utilized and the deployment option to Houston being dismissed I asked why, and the response was that he was told to stand down on this issue.

15.         From my perspective, my SOR, at that time and maybe still is, the “deciding official” was working with me, both of us trying to work something out, which we did, and his decision was overruled.

16.         Why?

17.         I would like to assume it was because of a concern over my health.

18.         If so, why not a virtual deployment option?

19.         I have spoken with SOR many times about my concerns over being underutilized and how I could do more for the mission.

20.         I was deployed, virtually, to 4611DR, (09/2021-05/2023) as a PDTFL.

21.         I worked virtually from 03/2020-09/2021.

22.         One 6-month deployment since 03/2020, which was problematic

 

Much of the following has not been addressed in the denial.

The denial must clearly state the specific reasons for the denial, which shall include, where applicable:

Why the requested accommodation would not be effective;

Why the requested accommodation would result in undue hardship to the Agency;

Whether medical documentation provided was inadequate to establish that the individual has a disability and/or needs a reasonable accommodation.

Whether the requested accommodation would require the removal of an essential job function; or

Whether the requested accommodation would require the lowering of a performance or production standard.

 

***Anna Myers email

1. After the interactive process 

2. considering your position description (attached),

a. Respondent comments

i. My understanding, at this time, is that the “essential function” impact identified is “deployment”.

ii. I can and do provide the essential functions and elements of the PDTFL position assist, PDTFL duties and responsibilities.

iii. The majority of my time with FEMA has been in a virtual status. 

3. the essential functions of your position, and 

a. Respondent comments

i. My understanding, at this time, is that the “essential function” impact identified is “deployment”.

ii. I can and do provide the essential functions and elements of the PDTFL position assist, PDTFL duties and responsibilities.

iii. The majority of my time with FEMA has been in a virtual status. 

4. your request for an accommodation (to work from home 100%), 

5. management has denied your reasonable accommodation request for the reasons indicated in the attached 256-02 form. 

6. If you believe that you are no longer able to perform the essential functions of your position,

a. Respondent comments

i. My understanding, at this time, is that the “essential function” impact identified is “deployment”.

ii. I can and do provide the essential functions and elements of the PDTFL position assist, PDTFL duties and responsibilities.

iii. The majority of my time with FEMA has been in a virtual status. 

 

7. you may request that the Agency consider reassigning you if there is a funded, open position, consistent with page 19 of the attached FEMA Instruction on Reasonable Accommodation.

a. Respondent comments

i. I would prefer to reach an acceptable accommodation in my current position if I can continue to support the mission.

ii. I am of the opinion that it would be imprudent to agree to a “Reasonable Accommodation of Last Resort” which would imply a really good and proper RA process with robust interactive discussion, exploring options, short term or long term options, etc.

iii. That did not happen.

iv. It was just pretty much if I can’t physically deploy, we can’t use you.

v. I don’t want to upset the apple cart here, I am just saying that I have successfully done this very job, virtually, since 09/2021.

vi. It’s not that I can’t do the job, the problem is the disability, apparently.  

vii. The finality of the “Last Resort”, that just doesn’t seem right because I’m of the opinion this was a very rushed process with little dialog, option exploring, etc.

8. Please note that all FEMA positions require the ability to deploy and other positions may not be able to facilitate an accommodation that requires 100% work from home without the ability to deploy.  

 If you would like to go this route, please respond by COB no later than August 23, 2024.

Respectfully, Anna Myers

J Hunter denial

1. After careful consideration, Mr. Max Meindl’s request to telework 100% of the time is denied.  

2. The approval to allow Mr. Meindl to telework 100% of the time would require that the Agency remove the essential function of deployment from his duties and responsibilities.  

a. Respondent comments

i. My understanding, at this time, is that the “essential function” impact identified is “deployment”.

ii. I can and do provide the essential functions and elements of the PDTFL position assist, PDTFL duties and responsibilities.

iii. The majority of my time with FEMA has been in a virtual status. 

iv. Primarily due to declining health

v. A proactive SOR and assistive leadership sought out and provided an effective accommodation process that enabled me to enjoy the privileges and benefits of employment.

vi. I have been,

1. virtually deployed (03/2020-05/2023) 

a. 38 months (not including this year), 48 months taking into account the past 10 months of little to no work to do.

2. physically deployed (09/2017-06/2018 (+/-) and 05/2023-11/2023.  

a. 15 months

a. 21 months

vii. The denial must clearly state the specific reasons for the denial, which shall include, where applicable:

1. Why the requested accommodation would not be effective;

2. Why the requested accommodation would result in undue hardship to the Agency;

3. Whether medical documentation provided was inadequate to establish that the individual has a disability and/or needs a reasonable accommodation;

4. Whether the requested accommodation would require the removal of an essential job function; or

5. Whether the requested accommodation would require the lowering of a performance or production standard.

3. Mr. Meindl signed his onboarding, acknowledging that his position required that he deploy.  

a. Also acknowledged the reasonable accommodation clause.

4. While I understand that Mr. Meindl has a disability;

ii. I do acknowledge limitations due to various conditions as stipulated in the appropriate documents and these do impact my physical ability to deploy.

vi. Yes, I don’t get out much except for essentials and my daughter drives me.

6. Finally, his branch (Infrastructure Branch, Recovery Division) supports disaster deployments on an almost daily basis.  

7. His temporary accommodation cannot continue as assignments of duties are totally unrelated to his current position of record and cannot be continued.

a. Respondent comments

i. Agreed but I am curious why, when asked by my SOR if I could deploy to Houston, I concurred and 9 minutes later he called back and told me he was overruled.

ii. I have spoken with SOR many times about my concerns over being underutilized and how I could do more for the mission.

iii. I was virtually deployed to 4611DR, (09/2021-04/2023) as a PDTFL.

iv. I worked virtually from 03/2020-09/2021.

v. One 6-month deployment since 03/2020, which was problematic.

Anthony In, denial

1. Mr. Max Meindl’s reasonable accommodation to seek 100% telework cannot be granted.  

2. It is understood that Mr. Meindl’s indication that he could deploy is close to his home; however, I cannot consider that in a decision to grant the request.  

3. The option presented by Mr. Meindl is not a viable solution as I cannot grant him the ability to limit his deployment location.  

4. Given that Mr. Meindl would need to be sent wherever the disaster is located and his inabilities to do would limit my ability, therefore, I must deny his request.

Greetings,

I am an Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) Specialist with the Office of Civil Rights (OCR), Internal Civil Rights Division (ICRD), Equal Employment Opportunity Branch (EEOB) and I have been assigned as the counselor for your informal EEO complaint. 

First, I would like to provide some information about the process and what to expect. The EEO process for a federal employee or job applicant, ensures your rights under federal civil rights laws that protect you from discrimination because of your race, color, religion, sex (including gender identity, sexual orientation, and pregnancy), national origin, age (40 or older), disability, or genetic information. The law also protects you from retaliation if you oppose employment discrimination, file a complaint of discrimination, or participate in the EEO complaint process (even if the complaint is not yours.) The OCR EEO office is neutral in the processing of all complaints, and we do not advocate for the complainant or the agency, we instead ensure the administrative process is executed according to the EEOC MD-110, 29 CFR 1614 and other federal laws as applicable.

When a decision is made in an EEO complaint the EEOC Administrative Judge (AJ) or the DHS- Civil Rights and Civil Liberties (CRCL) Final Agency Decision (FAD) writer will be looking at whether the complaint shows a connection or nexus between the actions taken in the complaint and the protected basis(es) claimed. The AJ or CRCL FAD writer will then look at whether management provided a non-discriminatory reason for taking that action. Please keep that in mind when providing information or supporting documentation for your complaint. The process looks at whether discrimination or harassment occurred because of a protected basis. The Agency has other avenues to address complaints that are not based on an EEO protected category, let us know if you need that information.

The first stage of the EEO process is informal counseling. We will have an initial interview where we will discuss: 1.) the EEO process, your role, and your rights and responsibilities, 2.) your complaint and the issues that you are bringing as part of your EEO complaint, and 3.) next steps in the EEO process.  In addition, I am providing some important information attached regarding the EEO process (see attached).   

The intake form was already completed with by you. If you have not done so already, please provide a timeline of events for the instances you wish to include in your EEO Complaint.  Be sure to include dates (mm/dd/yy) of when the alleged incidents in your complaint occurred. If you don’t have the exact date, please try to provide at least the month and year of when the alleged incident(s) occurred. Attached are several documents required to get the process started. 

Our records reflect your initial contact date with EEOB as July 25, 2024, when we received an e-mail/call from you on this date.  Since I only have 30 days from initial contact to counsel your case and to attempt an informal resolution in accordance with applicable EEO regulations, I have attached an extension request that extends the informal counseling period an additional 60 days to ensure we have sufficient time for informal counseling.  If you agree to the extension, please read, sign, and return that document as well.  Also attached is your Notice of Rights and Responsibilities in the EEO process. Please read and initial each line and sign and return. If you have any questions, we can discuss them when we meet.

During the informal EEO process, you have the right to elect traditional EEO counseling or Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) as an option to resolve your complaint.  In traditional EEO counseling, the assigned EEO counselor serves as a go between and communicates your concerns and remedies requested to management and attempts to resolve the issue(s), as well as conducts a limited inquiry to collect additional information regarding your claims. ADR or mediation is an informal meeting between you and management that is conducted by a neutral mediator. The mediator is trained to help people who have disagreements talk to each other.  The mediator does not decide who is right or wrong or issue a decision.  During mediation you can voice your concerns and the mediator assists all parties in effectively communicating. The mediator does not decide who is right or wrong or issue a decision.  Instead, the mediator helps the parties work out their own solutions to their dispute. 

 There are real advantages to participating in ADR.  ADR offers both you and the agency the opportunity for a fast and informal settlement of the dispute.  Rather than leaving the decision to a third party (such as an Administrative Judge), ADR gives you the opportunity to reach an agreement that works for both you and the agency. During mediation all parties are together in one room or over Teams/Zoom. The process begins with the mediator explaining the procedure. Each party gets an opportunity to tell their side of the dispute. If a settlement is reached, a written agreement is drawn up, signed by all parties, and is binding by all parties. This process is voluntary and highly recommended in resolving workplace disputes at the lowest level.

Once I get all your information back, I would like to set up a time for us to discuss your concerns.  The EEO process is time sensitive so please return all your documents to me within 2 business days.  Also, could you please include your working hours and availability when you return your information? 

Please choose one of the current available dates:

•             Wednesday, 18, 2024-

               9:00am – 10:00am (EST)

               10:00am –11:00 am (EST)

              11:00 am EST-12:00 pm (EST)

•             

Please reach out to me if you have any questions.

 

 

V/R

 

 

 

Janet Kelley

Equal Employment Specialist

FEMA, Department of Homeland Security

From: Kelley, Janet <janet.kelley@fema.dhs.gov> 
Sent: Tuesday, September 17, 2024 2:10 PM
To: Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: EEO Contact -HS-FEMA-03389-2024

 

Greetings,

I am an Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) Specialist with the Office of Civil Rights (OCR), Internal Civil Rights Division (ICRD), Equal Employment Opportunity Branch (EEOB) and I have been assigned as the counselor for your informal EEO complaint. 

First, I would like to provide some information about the process and what to expect. The EEO process for a federal employee or job applicant, ensures your rights under federal civil rights laws that protect you from discrimination because of your race, color, religion, sex (including gender identity, sexual orientation, and pregnancy), national origin, age (40 or older), disability, or genetic information. The law also protects you from retaliation if you oppose employment discrimination, file a complaint of discrimination, or participate in the EEO complaint process (even if the complaint is not yours.) The OCR EEO office is neutral in the processing of all complaints, and we do not advocate for the complainant or the agency, we instead ensure the administrative process is executed according to the EEOC MD-110, 29 CFR 1614 and other federal laws as applicable.

When a decision is made in an EEO complaint the EEOC Administrative Judge (AJ) or the DHS- Civil Rights and Civil Liberties (CRCL) Final Agency Decision (FAD) writer will be looking at whether the complaint shows a connection or nexus between the actions taken in the complaint and the protected basis(es) claimed. The AJ or CRCL FAD writer will then look at whether management provided a non-discriminatory reason for taking that action. Please keep that in mind when providing information or supporting documentation for your complaint. The process looks at whether discrimination or harassment occurred because of a protected basis. The Agency has other avenues to address complaints that are not based on an EEO protected category, let us know if you need that information.

The first stage of the EEO process is informal counseling. We will have an initial interview where we will discuss: 1.) the EEO process, your role, and your rights and responsibilities, 2.) your complaint and the issues that you are bringing as part of your EEO complaint, and 3.) next steps in the EEO process.  In addition, I am providing some important information attached regarding the EEO process (see attached).   

The intake form was already completed with by you. If you have not done so already, please provide a timeline of events for the instances you wish to include in your EEO Complaint.  Be sure to include dates (mm/dd/yy) of when the alleged incidents in your complaint occurred. If you don’t have the exact date, please try to provide at least the month and year of when the alleged incident(s) occurred. Attached are several documents required to get the process started. 

Our records reflect your initial contact date with EEOB as July 25, 2024, when we received an e-mail/call from you on this date.  Since I only have 30 days from initial contact to counsel your case and to attempt an informal resolution in accordance with applicable EEO regulations, I have attached an extension request that extends the informal counseling period an additional 60 days to ensure we have sufficient time for informal counseling.  If you agree to the extension, please read, sign, and return that document as well.  Also attached is your Notice of Rights and Responsibilities in the EEO process. Please read and initial each line and sign and return. If you have any questions, we can discuss them when we meet.

During the informal EEO process, you have the right to elect traditional EEO counseling or Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) as an option to resolve your complaint.  In traditional EEO counseling, the assigned EEO counselor serves as a go between and communicates your concerns and remedies requested to management and attempts to resolve the issue(s), as well as conducts a limited inquiry to collect additional information regarding your claims. ADR or mediation is an informal meeting between you and management that is conducted by a neutral mediator. The mediator is trained to help people who have disagreements talk to each other.  The mediator does not decide who is right or wrong or issue a decision.  During mediation you can voice your concerns and the mediator assists all parties in effectively communicating. The mediator does not decide who is right or wrong or issue a decision.  Instead, the mediator helps the parties work out their own solutions to their dispute. 

 There are real advantages to participating in ADR.  ADR offers both you and the agency the opportunity for a fast and informal settlement of the dispute.  Rather than leaving the decision to a third party (such as an Administrative Judge), ADR gives you the opportunity to reach an agreement that works for both you and the agency. During mediation all parties are together in one room or over Teams/Zoom. The process begins with the mediator explaining the procedure. Each party gets an opportunity to tell their side of the dispute. If a settlement is reached, a written agreement is drawn up, signed by all parties, and is binding by all parties. This process is voluntary and highly recommended in resolving workplace disputes at the lowest level.

Once I get all your information back, I would like to set up a time for us to discuss your concerns.  The EEO process is time sensitive so please return all your documents to me within 2 business days.  Also, could you please include your working hours and availability when you return your information? 

Please choose one of the current available dates:

•             Wednesday, 18, 2024-

               9:00am – 10:00am (EST)

               10:00am –11:00 am (EST)

              11:00 am EST-12:00 pm (EST)

•             

Please reach out to me if you have any questions.

 

 

V/R

 

 

 

Janet Kelley

Equal Employment Specialist

Office: Office of Civil Rights (OCR) 

FEMA, Department of Homeland Security

Subject: RA Decision

 

Good afternoon Meindl,   

  

As per policy and the interactive discussion that was held on today, “If an employee is denied their request for reasonable accommodation, they may appeal directly to their second level supervisor within ten (10) calendar days of the employee’s receipt of the decision. The employee may present additional information in support of their request. The second level supervisor will respond to this request within ten (10) calendar days of receipt of the request. The appeal decision must be reviewed by OCR within ten (10) days prior to issuance.” 

  

Your second line SOR is Jodi Hunter. Please submit your request directly to Jodi Hunter and copy me, (RA Specialist) for awareness purposes and to begin the interactive process for the appeal.  

  

You have been provided with the FF-256 page 2 Management Response decision document and any additional questions regarding the grounds for the initial denial may be discussed with your SOR.  

  

Shelia Clemons

Respectfully,

Subject: RA Decision

 

Good afternoon Meindl,   

  

As per policy and the interactive discussion that was held on today, “If an employee is denied their request for reasonable accommodation, they may appeal directly to their second level supervisor within ten (10) calendar days of the employee’s receipt of the decision. The employee may present additional information in support of their request. The second level supervisor will respond to this request within ten (10) calendar days of receipt of the request. The appeal decision must be reviewed by OCR within ten (10) days prior to issuance.” 

  

Your second line SOR is Jodi Hunter. Please submit your request directly to Jodi Hunter and copy me, (RA Specialist) for awareness purposes and to begin the interactive process for the appeal.  

  

You have been provided with the FF-256 page 2 Management Response decision document and any additional questions regarding the grounds for the initial denial may be discussed with your SOR.  

  

Shelia Clemons

From: Aybar-Morales, Miriam <miriam.aybarmorales@fema.dhs.gov> 
Sent: Thursday, August 4, 2022 2:28 PM
To: Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov>
Cc: Mckenzie, Rachel <rachel.mckenzie@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: RE: RAR0042452 for Telework: 100% 

 

Thank you for contacting the OER Disability Unit <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/SitePages/Reasonable-Accommodation-(RA).aspx> .  The OER Disability Unit provides oversight to ensure the timely processing of your RA request is consistent with all relevant statutes, regulations, EEOC, case law and the FEMA Reasonable Accommodation Policy. The deciding official for your RA request is your first line supervisor of record (SOR).  In that regard OER provides neutral, authoritative guidance to both managers/supervisors and employees on the RA process.

 

Attached is the FEMA Form 256-0-1 Request for Reasonable Accommodation <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/OER%20Forms/Request%20Reasonable%20Accommodation%20Form%20256-0-1.pdf> , as well as the FEMA Fact Sheet Guide to the Reasonable Accommodation Process and Deployments. <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/OAI/ooer/Documents/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=%2Fsites%2FOAI%2Fooer%2FDocuments%2FLaws%2C%20Authorities%2C%20Statements%2FRA%20Policies%2FReasonable%20Accommodation%20Process%20During%20Deployment%5FFact%20Sheet%5F508v%2Epdf&parent=%2Fsites%2FOAI%2Fooer%2FDocuments%2FLaws%2C%20Authorities%2C%20Statements%2FRA%20Policies>  The fact sheet explains the RA process in a nutshell, outlines the criteria that must be met to be considered a qualified person with a disability, as well as the criteria for sufficient medical documentation. Please note that we cannot proceed with processing your accommodation request before we receive adequate medical documentation.  The ADA requires an employer to provide reasonable accommodations to qualified individuals with disabilities who are employees or applicants for employment, unless to do so would cause an undue hardship. The ADA defines an individual with a disability as a person who experiences substantial impairment in performing one or more major life activities, such as walking and hearing.  

 

I understand that you have requested “Continued Remote/telework, permanent exemption from the report to office mandate.

“ as an RA for disability. Note that an RA for disability is never permanent and must be reassessed annually. Furthermore, requests for indefinite periods of full-time telework are considered requests for remote work and are subject to the policy and procedures outlined in the  Remote Work Manual <https://usfema.sharepoint.com/sites/MSFOW/WorkplacePolicyandForms/Forms/AllItems.aspx?id=%2Fsites%2FMSFOW%2FWorkplacePolicyandForms%2FRemote%20Work&viewid=5e80857f%2D6001%2D4c4a%2Dad58%2Dc7d8ac04e446> . Remote work is not considered an RA for disability, due to the aforementioned policy limiting the effective dates of an approved RA to one calendar year. 

 

If you wish to pursue a request for remote work, please let us know by COB on Thursday August 11th,  so that we can update and close this RA ticket in a timely manner. 

 

If you are a person with a disability and wish to request telework as an accommodation for your impairment, please follow the next steps outlined below. A first line supervisor of record may consider granting up to 90 days of full-time situational telework as an RA for disability, a second line supervisor may consider extending a full-time situational telework agreement for up to one year. 

 

NEXT STEPS:

 

To formalize an RA request, please amend page one of your FEMA Form 256 to include the effective dates that you are requesting full-time situational telework. Return the amended 256 to me by COB on Thursday August 18th, along with supporting medical documentation. Medical documentation does not need to be shared with your SOR, and you may choose to remove them from the thread before sending your password protected and/or encrypted medical documentation. Please be aware that sufficient medical documentation must come from a medical professional familiar with your disability, must be on their letterhead, signed, dated, and must contain all of the following information:

 

Criteria for sufficient medical documentation:

1.	Describes the nature, severity, and duration of the individual’s impairment;
2.	The major life activity or activities that the impairment limits; 
3.	The extent to which the impairment limits the individual’s ability to perform said activity or activities; 
4.	Substantiates why the requested reasonable accommodation is needed; and,
5.	Why the individual requires the particular reasonable accommodation requested, as well as 
6.	How the accommodation will assist the individual in performing the essential functions of the job.

 

The DHS COVID Vaccination Medical Exception Form uploaded with this RA request is not sufficient to substantiate an RA request of any kind. Note that this form applies only to requests for exemption from the COVID vaccination mandate, which is not currently enforced by any Federal agency due to legal injunction. If and when DHS-HQ resumes adjudication of vaccine exemption requests, please be sure that they are in receipt of a signed DHS COVID Vaccination Medical Exception Form. For your situational awareness, the document attached to this RA ticket was neither signed nor dated. 

 

Respectfully, 

Miriam Aybar-Morales

Senior RA Specialist – Team Lead – COR II| Disability Unit| Office of Equal Rights

FEMA | U.S. Department of Homeland Security

My RA has been denied.

How do I validate/verify the required OER/OCC participation/review?

 

RE:

Prior to denying a request for reasonable accommodation for an applicant or employee, the Deciding Official and the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) must consult with the OCC embedded attorney in OCR to articulate the specific reasons for the denial. The Deciding Official in coordination with the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) will draft the denial decision. The OCR Director must review and concur with all denial decisions within 3 business days of the denial decision

 

Thank you for your assistance.

From: Meindl, Max 
Sent: Monday, August 12, 2024 7:19 AM
To: FEMA-OCR-RA <FEMA-OCR-RA@fema.dhs.gov>
Subject: RE: RAR0046767

 

My RA has been denied.

How do I validate/verify the required OER/OCC participation/review?

 

RE: From policy

Prior to denying a request for reasonable accommodation for an applicant or employee, the Deciding Official and the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) must consult with the OCC embedded attorney in OCR to articulate the specific reasons for the denial. The Deciding Official in coordination with the RA Specialist (assigned to the employee request) will draft the denial decision. The OCR Director must review and concur with all denial decisions within 3 business days of the denial decision

 

From fact sheet.

How is a decision reached regarding a request for a reasonable accommodation? 

FEMA is required to initiate an interactive discussion with individuals who request an accommodation. It is through this discussion that the SOR learns about the employee’s limitations and types of accommodations which would be the most effective to enable the employee to perform the essential functions of his/her job. The SOR may consult with OER, if assistance is needed. The final decision rests with the SOR; however, a SOR may not issue a denial without the concurrence of OER. Once decided, the SOR must meet with the employee to discuss the decision and provide them the decision in writing. Once issued, a copy of the decision must be forwarded to OER.

 

Thank you for your assistance.

___________________________________

Max J Meindl, PMP

Emergency Management Specialist | PDTFL
