		Ms. Kelley: 

		 

		I spoke with my client, and I need to understand where the date of October 3, 2024 comes from. Without further information and clarification of why that is the date that should be used I cannot advise my client to sign the document. My client would like to have this process resolved expeditiously and conveniently for all parties involved. 

		 

		It is my understanding that the incidents and causes for my client's complaint have been ongoing and occurring essentially continuously since near the beginning of the year. My client informed me and provided the communications regarding the timing of his complaint and the submission of forms. It appears to me that the form was submitted on September 3, 2024 and acknowledged on September 13, 2024. 

		 

		I cannot advise my client to sign a form with a date that is inaccurate, and could potentially invalidate claims and worse be used as a document against him signing something that is inaccurate. I understand there are timing issues involved in this process and deadlines that must be met. But I cannot advise him to sign without further clarification on the October 3, 2024 date.

		 

		Thank you, 

		Brent Smith

			Good afternoon Mr. Smith,

			 

			Thank you for email.  For clarification, your client expressed his intent to file an EEO complaint when he returned his intake form on Sep 3, 2024.  And that is the correct date that should be in the extension letter. Again, I apologize for the confusion.

			 

			Please let me know if you have any additional questions and concerns.

			 

			Kindest regards,

			 

			 

			Janet Kelley

			Equal Employment Specialist

			Office: Office of Civil Rights (OCR) 

			FEMA, Department of Homeland Security

			From: Brent Smith <brent@bwsmithlaw.com <mailto:brent@bwsmithlaw.com> > 
			Sent: Thursday, October 17, 2024 12:30 PM

			CAUTION: This email originated from outside of DHS. DO NOT click links or open attachments unless you recognize and/or trust the sender. Please select the Phish Alert Report button on the top right of your screen to report this email if it is unsolicited or suspicious in nature.

			 

			Ms. Kelley: 

			 

			I spoke with my client, and I need to understand where the date of October 3, 2024 comes from. Without further information and clarification of why that is the date that should be used I cannot advise my client to sign the document. My client would like to have this process resolved expeditiously and conveniently for all parties involved. 

			 

			It is my understanding that the incidents and causes for my client's complaint have been ongoing and occurring essentially continuously since near the beginning of the year. My client informed me and provided the communications regarding the timing of his complaint and the submission of forms. It appears to me that the form was submitted on September 3, 2024 and acknowledged on September 13, 2024. 

			 

			I cannot advise my client to sign a form with a date that is inaccurate, and could potentially invalidate claims and worse be used as a document against him signing something that is inaccurate. I understand there are timing issues involved in this process and deadlines that must be met. But I cannot advise him to sign without further clarification on the October 3, 2024 date.

			 

			Thank you, 

			Brent Smith

Subject: EEO ADR Mediation Assignment- HS-FEMA-02430-2024
Body:
Good morning,

 

Thank you for agreeing to participate in ADR-Mediation.  I am the assigned ADR Program Manager assisting with the Mediation process.  Your assigned mediator is Greta Schauer.  You should receive a TEAMS Invite for your participation in the mediation scheduled for November 6, 2024 (8:00 am – 12:00 pm EST), from Greta Schauer.  Please “accept” the invitation as quickly as possible.  Reach out to me if you have not received the TEAMS Invite within one week prior to your scheduled mediation or if you have additional questions regarding the mediation process.  Reply to this email with confirmation that you have received and accepted the TEAMS Invite by November 2, 2024, from the assigned mediator.  

Again, thank you for your participation in ADR-Mediation.  

Please reach out to me if you have any questions or concerns related to the mediation process.

V/r

 

Carletta L. McDowell

ADR Program Manager

FEMA, Office of Civil Rights

EEO Branch

U.S. Department of Homeland Security

Mobile:  (771) 444-0976

carletta.mcdowell@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:carletta.mcdowell@fema.dhs.gov> 

Preferred Pronouns – She/Her

Federal Emergency Management Agency

fema.gov <http://www.fema.gov/>

Subject: Completion of FEMA Search for Reassignment
Body:
Hello Max, 

I am writing to inform you about the recent completion of a search for reassignment within FEMA, conducted as a reasonable accommodation in alignment with the criteria you provided.

Regrettably, after a thorough review, we have not identified any vacant positions within FEMA suitable for accommodating your specific needs. Consequently, we have concluded this phase of the search.

Should you have any concerns or disagree with the findings of this search, please do not hesitate to reach out to Mr. Jerron Carter, Branch Chief, Program Services Branch, Human Resources Operations, Office of the Chief Human Capital Officer, at jerron.carter@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:jerron.carter@fema.dhs.gov> . Mr. Carter would be pleased to discuss any specific vacancies you believe may align with your qualifications, with or without reasonable accommodations.

Furthermore, for any questions or further clarification regarding the next steps or other matters related to our efforts to provide you with reasonable accommodation, please contact Mr. Alejandro Ortiz, Disability Program Manager, Office of Equal Rights, at alejandro.ortiz@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:alejandro.ortiz@fema.dhs.gov> .

Thank you for your understanding, and we look forward to assisting you further.

 

Mayowa Onukwubiri
HR Advisor | Disaster Field Operations Division | OCHCO

Mobile: (202) 812-6325  

mayowa.onukwubiri@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:mayowa.onukwubiri@fema.dhs.gov> 

 

Federal Emergency Management Agency
fema.gov <http://www.fema.gov/>

Subject: Re: new
Body:
CAUTION: This email originated from outside of DHS. DO NOT click links or open attachments unless you recognize and/or trust the sender. Please select the Phish Alert Report button on the top right of your screen to report this email if it is unsolicited or suspicious in nature.

Max: 

It seems like they might be trying to set you up for not working. Are you able to spend your day bugging people for tasks and assignments? If you spend 8 hours a day trying to find work at least it puts the failure on them. But I am honestly at a loss as to what to advise. 

It seems like for them to require you to justify what you do for 8 hours each day cannot be held against you when they refuse to provide sufficient work. Especially when work exists, they just want to stand on their weird "determination" that remote work is not allowed even though it is a perfectly acceptable accommodation. 

Brent

On Wed, Nov 13, 2024 at 9:10 AM Meindl, Max <max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov> > wrote:

Subject: Re: FW: RAR0046767 Final Agency Denial Letter
Body:
CAUTION: This email originated from outside of DHS. DO NOT click links or open attachments unless you recognize and/or trust the sender. Please select the Phish Alert Report button on the top right of your screen to report this email if it is unsolicited or suspicious in nature.

Max: 

From the beginning I have believed they are just simply wrong that they cannot accommodate you in this manner simply by saying deployment is an essential function that cannot be accommodated by telework. It looks like they are really going to just push this and force you to file a lawsuit or give up. I am not sure what to advise on how to handle it. 

You have 45 days to address this with EEO. It might be worth looking for and discussing with an EEO specialty attorney. I can try and talk with the attorneys I know to see if they know of anyone or work on those types of cases. Especially if we can find one willing to take it on contingency. 

Also what does this mean for the reset on the mediation Wednesday, December 4th?

Regards,
Brent

Subject: RE: FW: RAR0046767 Final Agency Denial Letter
Body:
IMO, the RA request, and the current ADR are separate tracks and Tony may or may not be aware of it.

The letter sounds/reads as if it was written by an attorney though, just saying.

And… we are in the middle of the EEO process right now, the ADR we are having meetings about.

The meeting is still a go and, unless I bring it up, not sure of anyone in the call, except me and you, would be aware of the letter, but I’m not sure of that at all.

The letter may have been written by the lawyer attending the meetings.

 

Thank you for your assistance.

___________________________________

Subject: Re: FW: RAR0046767 Final Agency Denial Letter
Body:
CAUTION: This email originated from outside of DHS. DO NOT click links or open attachments unless you recognize and/or trust the sender. Please select the Phish Alert Report button on the top right of your screen to report this email if it is unsolicited or suspicious in nature.

I think at this point we should attend the meeting. I recommend we not bring it up or discuss it unless they do. I agree that an attorney wrote the letter. There is certainly language designed to argue that because you cannot perform the essential function of deploying that is the grounds for the denial.  

It is my argument though that it is an essential function that can be accommodated. Further, they have accommodated for years, and in a way by only requiring 4 in office attendance days per pay period they essentially make the in office requirement less than the ability to work via telework anyway. That in and of itself tells me that they can accommodate, it is a reasonable accommodation, but they are refusing to recognize that. I believe I know the reason as we discussed, but unfortunately that will be very difficult to prove. But I believe that it is in bad faith, and again unfortunately will likely require a lawsuit to get the relief I believe you are entitled to and not exactly a great option to pursue. 

Brent

Subject: Re: FW: RAR0046767 Final Agency Denial Letter
Body:
CAUTION: This email originated from outside of DHS. DO NOT click links or open attachments unless you recognize and/or trust the sender. Please select the Phish Alert Report button on the top right of your screen to report this email if it is unsolicited or suspicious in nature.

Max: 

I went back and looked at the Enforcement Guidance on Reasonable Accommodation and found this. Which is different than my initial understanding of essential function accommodation. The relevant passage is below:


There are several modifications or adjustments that are not considered forms of reasonable accommodation. An employer does not have to eliminate an essential function, i.e., a fundamental duty of the position. This is because a person with a disability who is unable to perform the essential functions, with or without reasonable accommodation, is not a "qualified" individual with a disability within the meaning of the ADA. Nor is an employer required to lower production standards -- whether qualitative or quantitative -- that are applied uniformly to employees with and without disabilities. However, an employer may have toprovide reasonable accommodation to enable an employee with a disability tomeet the production standard. While an employer is not required to eliminate an essential function or lower a production standard, it may do so if it wishes.


The problem I have is that they have accommodated this for years, and even the fact that they require in office less than 40% of the time. It seems to me they could if they chose to accommodate around this essential function. Maybe a reasonable accommodation is some level of in office that is less than what is required but you do occasionally work in office. I am just not sure how much they are willing to work with you. I also realize that this mediation is not exactly for the accommodations portions, but I do not see why they cannot eliminate the issue by finding a compromise.

Regards,
Brent

	It is my argument though that it is an essential function that can be accommodated. That in and of itself tells me that they can accommodate, it is a reasonable accommodation, but they are refusing to recognize that. I believe I know the reason as we discussed, but unfortunately that will be very difficult to prove. But I believe that it is in bad faith, and again unfortunately will likely require a lawsuit to get the relief I believe you are entitled to and not exactly a great option to pursue. 

	Brent

Subject: NRTF-HS-FEMA-02430-2024
Body:
Greetings, 

 

Since your EEO complaint was not resolved.  You, now, have the right to file a formal EEO complaint to continue in the EEO process.

 

Therefore, please find the Notice of Right to File a Formal Complaint attached.  Please acknowledge receipt to let me know that the document has been received, then, I will send you the FORMAL FORM.

 

Please let me know if you have any questions. 

 

Thank you.

 

 

Janet Kelley

Equal Employment Specialist

Office: Office of Civil Rights (OCR) 

FEMA, Department of Homeland Security

Email: janet.kelley@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:janet.kelley@fema.dhs.gov>  I Pronouns: she/her

Subject: RE: NRTF-HS-FEMA-02430-2024
Body:
acknowledge receipt

 

Thank you for your assistance.

___________________________________

Max J Meindl, PMP

Emergency Management Specialist

Recovery Division | Region Six

Mobile: 202-374-9426

max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:max.meindl@fema.dhs.gov> 

 

Federal Emergency Management Agency 

www.FEMA.gov <http://www.fema.gov/>

Hello,

 

Please see attached. Your formal is due by December 20, 2024. Please send it to Angela.McGonigal@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:Angela.McGonigal@fema.dhs.gov>  and FEMA-OCR-EEO@fema.dhs.gov <mailto:FEMA-OCR-EEO@fema.dhs.gov> . 

 

Reminder: Any claims outside of 45 days has a possibility of being dismissed for untimely counseling contact.
